description: In this series, Sean and Mike explore several tools that are commonly used for Penetration Testing. They show how the tools work, and explore their functionality. They also demonstrate how to create your own tools, like loading Kali Nethunter on a Nexus 7 and creating your own PwnPad.
name: Security Tech Skills
subtitle: Commonly used penetration tools

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike take a look at Kali 2.0. They talk about the major changes from Kali 1.0, and explore the new interface. They also talk about the different versions available, and the new update model.
episodes.title: Introducing Kali 2.0
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.012 --> 00:00:03.059
[SOUND]

2
00:00:03.059 --> 00:00:09.973
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:09.973 --> 00:00:12.640
Hello and
welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.640 --> 00:00:14.330
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

5
00:00:14.330 --> 00:00:17.150
With me today is the famous Sean Oriyano.

6
00:00:17.150 --> 00:00:20.090
And in this episode Sean
we're going to be covering

7
00:00:20.090 --> 00:00:24.970
Kali which is something we've got some
other episodes on but this is Kali 2.0.

8
00:00:24.970 --> 00:00:26.400
Some big changes and

9
00:00:26.400 --> 00:00:29.320
a lot of stuff that we really need
to take a look at, right Sean?

10
00:00:29.320 --> 00:00:31.020
>> Yeah, absolutely.

11
00:00:31.020 --> 00:00:35.252
You know, as Mike said,
we have talked about Kali

12
00:00:35.252 --> 00:00:40.220
before and it's been around for a while.

13
00:00:40.220 --> 00:00:42.900
And so
it wasn't actually all that long ago,

14
00:00:42.900 --> 00:00:47.050
a couple months ago we just got
finished talking about 1.0.

15
00:00:47.050 --> 00:00:51.145
So what we're doing now of course,
we're talking about 2.0.

16
00:00:51.145 --> 00:00:56.660
2.0 was released the middle of August,
August eleventh to be specific.

17
00:00:56.660 --> 00:01:02.300
And some of you may have gotten
ahold of it at that point in time.

18
00:01:02.300 --> 00:01:06.170
That's actually a good feat if you did,
because it was, the offensive security

19
00:01:06.170 --> 00:01:10.820
site was really beaten up that day
because it was such a big deal.

20
00:01:10.820 --> 00:01:13.990
This was actually debuted at DEF CON.

21
00:01:13.990 --> 00:01:18.500
So, that's why they held off and
held off and held off.

22
00:01:18.500 --> 00:01:23.115
You saw some before the official
announcement at DEF CON, or

23
00:01:23.115 --> 00:01:28.726
official debut at DEF CON, you saw
some images getting bounced around and

24
00:01:28.726 --> 00:01:33.820
stuff like that but the real official
one came out right at DEF CON.

25
00:01:33.820 --> 00:01:38.260
They did some training there and then the
rest of the world started seeing it and

26
00:01:38.260 --> 00:01:40.180
it's still pretty new to most people.

27
00:01:40.180 --> 00:01:44.500
I mean we're barely talking a month that
the thing has been out, so there's a lot

28
00:01:44.500 --> 00:01:49.630
of people out there still learning it and
getting used to this whole new version.

29
00:01:49.630 --> 00:01:53.010
Which it really is, when you look at it,
is a whole new version.

30
00:01:53.010 --> 00:01:56.920
Even though you may not think
that it's anything more than just

31
00:01:56.920 --> 00:02:01.840
an upgrade to the existing one, which is
true, it is an upgrade, but there's so

32
00:02:01.840 --> 00:02:04.190
much more to that that we're
trying to introduce here.

33
00:02:04.190 --> 00:02:09.190
So enough that we're gonna spend some
serious time talking about what makes it

34
00:02:09.190 --> 00:02:14.280
different, some things you can do with it,
and just kind of

35
00:02:14.280 --> 00:02:19.990
get you familiarized with the differences
in this product over the previous one.

36
00:02:19.990 --> 00:02:23.010
Now, that doesn't mean,
even though there's some new stuff, or

37
00:02:23.010 --> 00:02:27.460
a good number of new things in Kali 2.0,
it doesn't mean that you

38
00:02:27.460 --> 00:02:32.280
can't go back to what we had in
the library already for 1.0.

39
00:02:32.280 --> 00:02:35.900
And use a lot of that knowledge, cuz
a lot of those tools have carried over.

40
00:02:35.900 --> 00:02:37.940
But there are some new tools as well, and

41
00:02:37.940 --> 00:02:42.940
we'll focus on those
whenever that comes up.

42
00:02:42.940 --> 00:02:47.290
So that's really kind of what
we're looking at here, and

43
00:02:47.290 --> 00:02:50.250
that's why we're doing this exploration.

44
00:02:50.250 --> 00:02:53.980
So let's just kinda talk about the first
thing, about some of the major things

45
00:02:53.980 --> 00:02:57.240
you're gonna notice with
Kali when you get into it.

46
00:02:57.240 --> 00:03:02.845
They did change the pronunciation of it,
you speak Kali now, it's Kali.

47
00:03:02.845 --> 00:03:06.940
[LAUGH] Just tell her that we
both pronounce it different,

48
00:03:06.940 --> 00:03:10.370
and there's not going to be a compromise.

49
00:03:10.370 --> 00:03:13.450
>> We're going to stick to our guns,
you know.

50
00:03:13.450 --> 00:03:15.378
>> You just choose the one
that's appropriate.

51
00:03:15.378 --> 00:03:20.217
[LAUGH]
Anyway,

52
00:03:20.217 --> 00:03:23.720
so, the major differences we
have between version one and

53
00:03:23.720 --> 00:03:27.620
two, probably the biggest thing people
are gonna notice is the interface.

54
00:03:27.620 --> 00:03:31.960
Interface is definitely different,
and I'll show you that in a bit.

55
00:03:31.960 --> 00:03:33.770
But the interface is different.

56
00:03:33.770 --> 00:03:39.130
It's not as, well it's a lot
cleaner is a better way to put it.

57
00:03:39.130 --> 00:03:44.265
It's a lot cleaner, it's organized
a bit differently over the 1.0 version.

58
00:03:44.265 --> 00:03:50.505
1.0 version if you get down to it, in fact
if you go from Backtrack over to Kali 1.0,

59
00:03:50.505 --> 00:03:55.790
to 2.0, you'll notice that the tools went
more from just being an afterthought

60
00:03:55.790 --> 00:03:58.900
to all of a sudden being part of the menu,
to having their own menu in there.

61
00:03:58.900 --> 00:04:02.550
And if you remember, when we did 1.0,
we went to the menu and

62
00:04:02.550 --> 00:04:06.770
we had to go all the way down
to the normal tools in Linux and

63
00:04:06.770 --> 00:04:11.570
there was a cascading menu that came
out for the penetration testing stuff.

64
00:04:11.570 --> 00:04:14.270
And that opened up into
several different levels.

65
00:04:14.270 --> 00:04:15.470
It's easy to get lost.

66
00:04:15.470 --> 00:04:16.380
When you get down to it.

67
00:04:16.380 --> 00:04:20.830
I mean, there were several times in the
demos here, that even though I knew where

68
00:04:20.830 --> 00:04:26.310
things were in Kali 1.0,
I would go through and find it,

69
00:04:26.310 --> 00:04:30.780
and I'd still have the menus that go and
popping in or snapping back or whatever.

70
00:04:30.780 --> 00:04:34.560
So what they've done is they fixed the
interface, or made it a little cleaner, so

71
00:04:34.560 --> 00:04:36.180
it's much more purpose built.

72
00:04:36.180 --> 00:04:40.420
This really truly is a penetration
testing tool when we go to 2.0.

73
00:04:40.420 --> 00:04:41.950
So that's a great thing.

74
00:04:41.950 --> 00:04:42.520
>> Nice.

75
00:04:42.520 --> 00:04:45.970
>> So, interface is a lot cleaner,
the tools that you would use,

76
00:04:45.970 --> 00:04:49.750
a lot of them are right
there on the surface.

77
00:04:49.750 --> 00:04:52.270
There's quick access menus in here, so and

78
00:04:52.270 --> 00:04:55.320
then there are a lot of other
little details in there.

79
00:04:55.320 --> 00:04:59.920
So, that's the biggest thing that you
are going to notice when you come into it.

80
00:04:59.920 --> 00:05:03.216
Okay, but just having a new
interface that's nothing really.

81
00:05:03.216 --> 00:05:07.620
It is a GNOME based interface by
the way for those of you keeping score.

82
00:05:07.620 --> 00:05:10.150
It is using the interface called GNOME.

83
00:05:10.150 --> 00:05:14.720
GNOME has been around for a while,
as one of the major Linux interfaces.

84
00:05:14.720 --> 00:05:18.020
So it's using GNOME, but it's been really,
really prettied up and cleaned up.

85
00:05:18.020 --> 00:05:19.220
But it looks quite nice.

86
00:05:19.220 --> 00:05:21.525
You know, so that's a big thing.

87
00:05:22.695 --> 00:05:25.805
As far as other changes
that have been done,

88
00:05:25.805 --> 00:05:30.705
this is fully supporting
Debian on the back end.

89
00:05:30.705 --> 00:05:37.675
So, we were using it,
which is a major distro of Linux.

90
00:05:37.675 --> 00:05:40.755
They're using Debian on the back end so

91
00:05:40.755 --> 00:05:45.230
that means that they're really unleashing,
unlocking the power of one of the full

92
00:05:45.230 --> 00:05:49.220
distros instead of going after something
like Ubuntu or something like that.

93
00:05:49.220 --> 00:05:52.720
They just bypassed it and
went right to what's behind Ubuntu and

94
00:05:52.720 --> 00:05:54.430
a lot of the other major ones.

95
00:05:54.430 --> 00:05:58.360
You know, there's some Some
benefits there too by the way,

96
00:05:58.360 --> 00:06:00.993
since Debian is a major distro of Linux.

97
00:06:00.993 --> 00:06:04.691
You've got a situation where there's
a lot of tools out there that

98
00:06:04.691 --> 00:06:08.256
are supported in that, so
it means that you can add on a lot of your

99
00:06:08.256 --> 00:06:11.467
own own tools to Kali to
enhance its functionality.

100
00:06:11.467 --> 00:06:14.242
And you're gonna wanna do that,
you're definitely gonna wanna do that.

101
00:06:14.242 --> 00:06:18.167
And I'm gonna show you
not only how to add tools

102
00:06:18.167 --> 00:06:23.160
into Kali your own, but I'm also going to
show you along the way how to make your

103
00:06:23.160 --> 00:06:25.780
own custom image that
incorporates those tools.

104
00:06:25.780 --> 00:06:29.280
So you're not stuck with just using
what offensive security provides,

105
00:06:29.280 --> 00:06:33.740
I'm also going to show you, hey,
take a base installation of KOE and

106
00:06:33.740 --> 00:06:36.470
install your own tools
into it from where ever.

107
00:06:36.470 --> 00:06:40.700
And then make your own ISO file out of it
which is a really neat ability to have.

108
00:06:41.780 --> 00:06:44.850
So those are some cool things.

109
00:06:44.850 --> 00:06:48.190
And then just one other
thing to mention here.

110
00:06:48.190 --> 00:06:51.080
Just remember we're just
doing the intro here.

111
00:06:51.080 --> 00:06:53.420
This isn't what it's limited to.

112
00:06:53.420 --> 00:06:54.950
Platform support.

113
00:06:54.950 --> 00:06:57.710
Platform support is much more broad,
I would say,

114
00:06:57.710 --> 00:07:00.960
with 2.0 than it was
with the previous one.

115
00:07:00.960 --> 00:07:06.555
2.0 supports a wider range of hardware

116
00:07:07.735 --> 00:07:13.925
than we had available or officially
supported for 1.0, which is really neat.

117
00:07:13.925 --> 00:07:15.905
You can install it in anything from, well,

118
00:07:15.905 --> 00:07:20.865
you could already do Kali 1.0 on
the Raspberry Pi, but you can do 2 on

119
00:07:20.865 --> 00:07:26.065
the Raspberry Pi plus a bunch of other
devices if you so choose to do that.

120
00:07:26.065 --> 00:07:30.060
In fact, I saw somebody which
you'll find out later on.

121
00:07:30.060 --> 00:07:33.870
I can't really find any logic
behind doing it just because,

122
00:07:33.870 --> 00:07:37.200
other than just saying that you did it,
which sometimes is enough, right?

123
00:07:37.200 --> 00:07:41.950
>> Right. [LAUGH] >> But
somebody installed Kali like we have here.

124
00:07:43.070 --> 00:07:47.757
They installed Kali right
on to their smart phone.

125
00:07:47.757 --> 00:07:51.426
Unfortunately, no one told them that we
already have a version of Kali designed

126
00:07:51.426 --> 00:07:52.302
for smart phones so

127
00:07:52.302 --> 00:07:55.556
they didn't have to spend a week in
their mom's basement doing that.

128
00:07:55.556 --> 00:07:59.143
[LAUGH] So oops, sorry.

129
00:07:59.143 --> 00:08:02.634
But let me just give you a quick
look at the interface so

130
00:08:02.634 --> 00:08:06.400
you kind of see what
we're talking about here.

131
00:08:06.400 --> 00:08:09.770
Is what I have brought up on my screen for

132
00:08:09.770 --> 00:08:13.410
you is I have Kali and
I have it running in virtual machine.

133
00:08:13.410 --> 00:08:15.390
So, just so you know.

134
00:08:15.390 --> 00:08:18.190
So it's running right
here in virtual machine.

135
00:08:18.190 --> 00:08:21.190
You can see it is a different interface.

136
00:08:21.190 --> 00:08:25.210
It's recognizable to things
you've seen in the past.

137
00:08:25.210 --> 00:08:31.610
This isn't really far removed
from what we had in Kali 1.0.

138
00:08:31.610 --> 00:08:34.400
But it is indeed different.

139
00:08:34.400 --> 00:08:37.660
You know, you can see it's a lot cleaner.

140
00:08:38.750 --> 00:08:41.350
We got the quick access
menus across the top.

141
00:08:41.350 --> 00:08:43.330
You know, the pull downs.

142
00:08:43.330 --> 00:08:46.120
You can see, we've got our other icons.

143
00:08:46.120 --> 00:08:48.280
I'm gonna show you the icons
in the upper right.

144
00:08:48.280 --> 00:08:51.100
There's actually some neat
things roaming around up there.

145
00:08:51.100 --> 00:08:52.610
But first of all,

146
00:08:52.610 --> 00:08:56.160
let me show you about the first part
of it with the applications menu.

147
00:08:56.160 --> 00:08:59.490
When you click on the applications menu,

148
00:08:59.490 --> 00:09:04.280
you'll notice right away that this is
a big deal when you get down to it.

149
00:09:04.280 --> 00:09:07.480
I mean, you look at it,
it's got this menu that just pops open.

150
00:09:07.480 --> 00:09:12.490
I mean take a look it's got everything
organized a lot more nicely for you.

151
00:09:12.490 --> 00:09:16.160
You can just instead of just having to go
through menu after menu after menu and

152
00:09:16.160 --> 00:09:19.120
keep going down to say I
wanted to do PEN testing.

153
00:09:19.120 --> 00:09:21.640
Then I do information gathering,
then I wanna open up this,

154
00:09:21.640 --> 00:09:23.420
then I wanna open up another sub-menu.

155
00:09:23.420 --> 00:09:24.200
You don't have to do that.

156
00:09:24.200 --> 00:09:28.780
And, that was something that I
found kinda irritating before.

157
00:09:28.780 --> 00:09:30.740
It was just, can we get on with it?

158
00:09:30.740 --> 00:09:32.930
You know, do I have to keep fishing and
digging around?

159
00:09:32.930 --> 00:09:34.060
I felt like I was getting a shovel and

160
00:09:34.060 --> 00:09:37.891
just having to keep digging a hole to
China in some cases, to get this stuff.

161
00:09:37.891 --> 00:09:40.206
>> [LAUGH]
>> I wanna get right to what I need to do,

162
00:09:40.206 --> 00:09:42.520
you know,
cuz I've got a thought process going.

163
00:09:42.520 --> 00:09:43.410
Whatever.

164
00:09:43.410 --> 00:09:46.880
So what you can do here is
just open the Applications.

165
00:09:46.880 --> 00:09:50.250
And it's got everything laid out there for
you, okay.

166
00:09:50.250 --> 00:09:52.990
What I do want you to keep in
mind when you're looking at this,

167
00:09:52.990 --> 00:09:57.670
though, is the fact that not
everything that's available

168
00:09:57.670 --> 00:10:00.840
in Kali is something that's
gonna show up on a menu.

169
00:10:00.840 --> 00:10:05.280
Kali has a substantial, there's
several hundred tools in this product.

170
00:10:05.280 --> 00:10:10.250
There's some tools that are strictly
available only at the command line.

171
00:10:10.250 --> 00:10:12.540
And you're gonna have to open
up a terminal window and

172
00:10:12.540 --> 00:10:14.150
actually type the name for the tool.

173
00:10:14.150 --> 00:10:16.190
Okay?
We haven't got there yet, but

174
00:10:16.190 --> 00:10:17.790
I'm just making you aware of that.

175
00:10:17.790 --> 00:10:22.270
Don't think that oh,
this is the extent of what you've got.

176
00:10:22.270 --> 00:10:25.050
No, it just means that they put some
of the more commonly used tools,

177
00:10:25.050 --> 00:10:27.970
they made them accessible to the menus for
you.

178
00:10:27.970 --> 00:10:32.660
And some of these tools that you'll
see on here available on these menus

179
00:10:32.660 --> 00:10:35.160
in fact themselves
are console based tools.

180
00:10:35.160 --> 00:10:38.180
They do not have a GUI, they're
just acting as a quick shortcut for

181
00:10:38.180 --> 00:10:40.450
you to click on and open the thing up.

182
00:10:40.450 --> 00:10:48.240
So, in that case I think that
to me is a big, big benefit.

183
00:10:48.240 --> 00:10:51.160
And you're gonna notice that there are
some new things as I scroll through it,

184
00:10:51.160 --> 00:10:56.340
but we'll talk about
those once we get there.

185
00:10:56.340 --> 00:10:59.310
We'll be talking about some of
those things as we go through.

186
00:10:59.310 --> 00:11:00.850
Won't be going through
every tool in there.

187
00:11:00.850 --> 00:11:02.860
Like I said, this isn't the time for that,

188
00:11:02.860 --> 00:11:08.470
cuz a lot of those tools are still
carryovers from previous versions.

189
00:11:08.470 --> 00:11:13.230
But there are some new ones
that are interesting and

190
00:11:13.230 --> 00:11:14.460
ones I wanna bring to your attention.

191
00:11:14.460 --> 00:11:18.050
And you're gonna have to augment what
we're doing here with some of your own

192
00:11:18.050 --> 00:11:18.734
exploration.

193
00:11:18.734 --> 00:11:21.336
[LAUGH] And trying out.

194
00:11:21.336 --> 00:11:25.040
But that's all well and good for that.

195
00:11:25.040 --> 00:11:29.800
I will tell you something here that's kind
of interesting about this metasploit.

196
00:11:29.800 --> 00:11:34.770
We did a whole series of classes,
you know, Mike and I on metasploit.

197
00:11:34.770 --> 00:11:38.100
Metasploit, you know, you can see that
it has this little shield you know,

198
00:11:38.100 --> 00:11:41.475
icon however saying
the Metasploit framework.

199
00:11:41.475 --> 00:11:45.845
That's just the basic Metasploit product.

200
00:11:45.845 --> 00:11:48.375
If you wanna upgrade for
anything for there, you wanna go

201
00:11:48.375 --> 00:11:52.205
to the higher end versions then you'll
have to actually download them.

202
00:11:52.205 --> 00:11:56.110
The versions that were available in
previous versions, they just said,

203
00:11:56.110 --> 00:11:57.250
we're not including that anymore.

204
00:11:57.250 --> 00:11:58.520
We'll just give you the basic stuff,

205
00:11:58.520 --> 00:12:01.210
if you wanna go up above that,
you're gonna have to go and download it.

206
00:12:01.210 --> 00:12:02.060
Go to Rapid7.

207
00:12:02.060 --> 00:12:04.020
They'll still give it to you, but

208
00:12:04.020 --> 00:12:06.860
you're gonna have to go
there to go get it yourself.

209
00:12:07.940 --> 00:12:11.360
Anyway, so I just pointed out there,

210
00:12:11.360 --> 00:12:14.040
you'll notice I pointed out
something on this left-hand side.

211
00:12:14.040 --> 00:12:17.230
This is your quick launch deal over here.

212
00:12:17.230 --> 00:12:20.170
You'll notice that it already has some
stuff that I have not changed since

213
00:12:20.170 --> 00:12:21.860
installation at all, by the way.

214
00:12:21.860 --> 00:12:26.500
This installation is just stock, so

215
00:12:26.500 --> 00:12:31.650
what I've got is, I have just some of
my more commonly used tools over there.

216
00:12:31.650 --> 00:12:33.550
And I can add to that whenever I want.

217
00:12:33.550 --> 00:12:36.930
In fact, I went in and added my terminal
window in there, or terminal window.

218
00:12:36.930 --> 00:12:40.635
You know, as one of the viewers in
here says, who uses the GUI anyway?

219
00:12:40.635 --> 00:12:42.330
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, well, you know,

220
00:12:42.330 --> 00:12:43.180
we do use the GUI.

00:25:34.000 --> 00:25:35.000
All kinds of good stuff.

449
00:25:35.000 --> 00:25:38.910
Looking forward to the rest of the show
as we cover some of those new features.

450
00:25:38.910 --> 00:25:41.040
But for now, we are out of time.

451
00:25:41.040 --> 00:25:44.040
So signing off for
ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

452
00:25:44.040 --> 00:25:45.100
>> And I am Sean Oriyano.

453
00:25:45.100 --> 00:25:46.140
>> And we'll see you tomorrow.

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike take a look at Kali Nethunter. They discuss the supported platforms for installing Nethunter. They also talk about some of the limitations of Kali Nethunter.
episodes.title: Kali Nethunter
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:09.984
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:09.984 --> 00:00:12.351
Hello, and
welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:12.351 --> 00:00:14.190
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:14.190 --> 00:00:16.230
With me today is Mr. Sean Oriyano.

5
00:00:16.230 --> 00:00:17.673
And Sean in this episode,

6

we're gonna be taking a look at
something called Kali NetHunter.

7

And this is similar to what we've
already been looking at, but

8
00:00:24.415 --> 00:00:26.110
it's slightly different.

9
00:00:26.110 --> 00:00:28.120
So what are the differences here, Sean?

10
00:00:28.120 --> 00:00:33.460
>> Well, it's one of those things that
it's the same, but it's different.

11
00:00:33.460 --> 00:00:38.930
It sounds like double speak,
and it is, but it isn't.

12
00:00:38.930 --> 00:00:43.850
That's the best way to see it,
it sounds like double speak, well it is,

13
00:00:43.850 --> 00:00:45.430
but it isn't.

14
00:00:45.430 --> 00:00:46.188
Stop doing that.

15
00:00:46.188 --> 00:00:52.260
>> [LAUGH] Can you use double
speak to explain double speak?

16
00:00:52.260 --> 00:00:53.560
That shouldn't be allowed.

17
00:00:53.560 --> 00:00:55.355
>> Well, apparently you can.

18
00:00:55.355 --> 00:00:57.010
[LAUGH]

19

here at IT Pro TV.

00:01:05.550 --> 00:01:08.090

Different option.

24
00:01:08.960 --> 00:01:09.880
Why would I want that one?

25
00:01:09.880 --> 00:01:10.580

26
00:01:10.580 --> 00:01:15.630
>> Yeah, they're both basically,
when we say the same, they both provide

27
00:01:15.630 --> 00:01:19.940
the same amount of functionality, the same
types of functionality in a broad sense.

28
00:01:19.940 --> 00:01:24.820
So, they're both siblings, cousins,
whatever you want to call it.

29
00:01:24.820 --> 00:01:27.250
You know the same type of thing.

30
00:01:27.250 --> 00:01:29.640
They are both used for pen testing.

31
00:01:29.640 --> 00:01:35.520
They have a lot of the same tools,
same between both of them.

32
00:01:35.520 --> 00:01:40.200
Not all of them, do not expect the same
stuff you see in Kali to jump ship and

33
00:01:40.200 --> 00:01:45.000
go right over to NetHunter,
but they are very close, and

34
00:01:45.000 --> 00:01:48.140
just because it is not in NetHunter
does not mean you either cannot

35
00:01:48.140 --> 00:01:51.510
put that tool in NetHunter, or
you can find an equivalent.

36
00:01:51.510 --> 00:01:58.190
You know, so it's the same in a lot of
senses, but it's not the same in others.

37
00:01:58.190 --> 00:02:03.510
Now, NetHunter is designed for mobile
devices and it's designed for mobile

38
00:02:03.510 --> 00:02:08.100
devices running In Android, so you're
not going to find anything, at least

39
00:02:08.100 --> 00:02:12.020
not right now or at least not supported
that's going to run anything like iOS.

40
00:02:12.020 --> 00:02:13.520
They designed it specifically for

41
00:02:13.520 --> 00:02:17.960
the Android platform, because basically
Android has got that Linux base.

42
00:02:17.960 --> 00:02:22.090
It's open and it's easy to develop for,
so they were able to go ahead and

43
00:02:22.090 --> 00:02:24.710
just port it over there fairly easily.

44
00:02:24.710 --> 00:02:31.730
And because they did that we've got all
this power in a very small form factor.

45
00:02:31.730 --> 00:02:33.840
A potentially small form factor.

46
00:02:33.840 --> 00:02:38.420
I've got my Nexus 5 device sitting here.

47
00:02:38.420 --> 00:02:43.184
My Nexus 5 device,
this does have Kali NetHunter on it and

48
00:02:43.184 --> 00:02:46.110
that means it's got a lot of power.

49
00:02:46.110 --> 00:02:47.380
I've taken Kali NetHunter,

50
00:02:47.380 --> 00:02:52.655
installed it on here, this is running
this latest version of Android.

51
00:02:52.655 --> 00:02:56.975
Not 6, but 5, 6 is unreleased so
just in case,

52
00:02:56.975 --> 00:03:02.055
but it's running a 5 series of Android,
and then it's got

53
00:03:02.055 --> 00:03:07.050
NetHunter installed on top of it, and then
I've done some modifications on to it,

54
00:03:07.050 --> 00:03:10.323
to kind of give it's own little upgrade
>> [LAUGH]

55
00:03:10.323 --> 00:03:12.230
>> And work out to make it all stronger.

56
00:03:12.230 --> 00:03:16.180
So there's a lot of power
sitting here in this device

57
00:03:17.240 --> 00:03:19.640
with the purpose of doing pen testing.

58
00:03:19.640 --> 00:03:21.230
So that's just a really neat thing.

59
00:03:22.280 --> 00:03:23.730
And really think about this for

60
00:03:23.730 --> 00:03:28.860
a second is that I have gone from having
to need something like my notebook,

61
00:03:28.860 --> 00:03:31.040
you know like I have got sitting
here right now in front of me,

62
00:03:31.040 --> 00:03:36.070
where I would have had to take this
notebook or you know to do the job before,

63
00:03:36.070 --> 00:03:39.930
you know I have gone from
notebook to you know this guy.

64
00:03:39.930 --> 00:03:44.430
You know so
it makes a tremendous amount of benefit.

65
00:03:44.430 --> 00:03:48.720
I like the fact the fact that with very
little effort I got this thing and

66
00:03:48.720 --> 00:03:51.860
I can just go through and slide it into
my pocket, it doesn't draw attention or

67
00:03:51.860 --> 00:03:54.830
anything else, I can let it run.

68
00:03:54.830 --> 00:03:59.500
It just makes my life easier,
makes it easier for

69
00:03:59.500 --> 00:04:05.250
me to blend in, than it would be for me to
pull out a notebook and start typing away.

70
00:04:05.250 --> 00:04:07.470
So there's a lot of benefits in this, and

71
00:04:07.470 --> 00:04:10.470
that's the great thing about NetHunter,
really.

72
00:04:10.470 --> 00:04:11.550
>> And that was a Nexus 5,

73
00:04:11.550 --> 00:04:14.310
which is definitely not the latest
Nexus that's out there.

74
00:04:14.310 --> 00:04:15.380
So that's kind of nice.

75
00:04:15.380 --> 00:04:17.668
I can go back to older hardware.

76
00:04:17.668 --> 00:04:21.419
I know Ben in our chatroom there
mentioned Nexus 5, 6 7 9, 10.

77
00:04:21.419 --> 00:04:27.360
So there's a lot of different platforms
that support or that we could put this on.

78
00:04:27.360 --> 00:04:28.890
>> Yeah, exactly.

79
00:04:28.890 --> 00:04:35.720
So it really opens up the options for you.

80
00:04:35.720 --> 00:04:38.470
So, kinda gotta really like that.

81
00:04:38.470 --> 00:04:43.390
In fact, as far as support goes,
what I've done to help you out here,

82
00:04:43.390 --> 00:04:47.540
on my screen,
this is on the Offensive Security site.

83
00:04:47.540 --> 00:04:53.208
These are the devices as of right

84
00:04:53.208 --> 00:05:00.096
so you've got Nexus 4 and 5, so
if you really want to go back to Nexus 4,

85
00:05:00.096 --> 00:05:06.230
I can't remember what age that is,
I want to say a 5 is 2013.

86
00:05:06.230 --> 00:05:12.580
So, a form of 4's going to
be a little older than that,

87
00:05:12.580 --> 00:05:17.590
and then you've got the Nexus 7,
very easy to get your hands on those.

88
00:05:17.590 --> 00:05:23.230
I've got three of those, and
two of them I got for together,

89
00:05:23.230 --> 00:05:28.220
brand new, for about 120 bucks for

90
00:05:28.220 --> 00:05:30.660
Easy to get your hands on and
do this stuff with.

91
00:05:30.660 --> 00:05:34.610
So you can build a pen testing

92
00:05:34.610 --> 00:05:41.430
There's the Nexus 10, the Nexus 6,
if you want another mobile phone.

93
00:05:41.430 --> 00:05:45.994
There's the 9 if you want a nice

00:05:45.994 --> 00:05:51.505
then there's even the one plus one phones,
told you I'd mess that up.

95
00:05:51.505 --> 00:05:52.800
>> [LAUGH]
>> I want to say one plus,

96
00:05:52.800 --> 00:05:54.830
and one plus one, whatever.

97
00:05:54.830 --> 00:05:57.824
I was going to say one plus one,
but no that sounds stupid,

98
00:05:57.824 --> 00:06:00.040
who would call their
device a one plus one?

99
00:06:00.040 --> 00:06:04.825
Well apparently, we've got Ben knows and
Kali knows, and I'm an idiot.

100
00:06:04.825 --> 00:06:09.680
>> [LAUGH]
>> But it gives you some pretty

00:06:09.680 --> 00:06:13.690
cool options, and
you can see here it's available in 2.0.

102
00:06:13.690 --> 00:06:18.540
So the code base and everything matches
what we have on the desktop side.

103
00:06:18.540 --> 00:06:21.660
And you can see what we have down here
at the bottom on the download page,

104
00:06:21.660 --> 00:06:26.840
you can see it even has, you know
those old names like KitKat, Lollipop,

105
00:06:26.840 --> 00:06:31.470
and those ones,
those are versions 4 and 5 of Android.

106
00:06:31.470 --> 00:06:33.070
That's what that refers to.

107
00:06:33.070 --> 00:06:33.750
Okay.

108
00:06:33.750 --> 00:06:37.530
Now don't worry, this is kind
of to give you the overview of

109
00:06:37.530 --> 00:06:42.860
what you can do with Kali,
or Kali NetHunter rather.

110
00:06:42.860 --> 00:06:46.580
One of the things we've got planned for

So we're gonna grab a Nexus 7 tablet, and

00:07:04.769 --> 00:07:09.270

00:07:09.270 --> 00:07:13.640
So if you guys want to start grabbing

00:07:13.640 --> 00:07:17.420
grab a Nexus 7 device and

118
00:07:17.420 --> 00:07:22.360
be prepared to do that along with us,
hey, you got that coming up,

00:07:22.360 --> 00:07:26.755
and I think we're scheduled to do that on

120
00:07:26.755 --> 00:07:29.250
>> [LAUGH]
>> Overnight shipping is what I'm talking

00:07:29.250 --> 00:07:29.860
about people.

122
00:07:29.860 --> 00:07:30.663
>> There you go.

123
00:07:30.663 --> 00:07:32.269
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So

00:07:32.269 --> 00:07:35.710
that should be exciting probably for

00:07:35.710 --> 00:07:40.480
And I would encourage you, I would

00:07:40.480 --> 00:07:46.520
use, to err try using Kali or
use an android device to do pen testing.

127
00:07:46.520 --> 00:07:48.372
It's a whole new experience.

128
00:07:48.372 --> 00:07:53.904
And I know some people have
actually downloaded tools like,

00:07:53.904 --> 00:07:57.374
there's one like IP Tools and Fing and

130
00:07:57.374 --> 00:08:01.712
stuff like that on the On

131
00:08:01.712 --> 00:08:06.052
we're way outside that
with Kali NetHunter and

00:08:06.052 --> 00:08:11.934
the device that I've got on me,
I've got way even beyond that.

133
00:08:11.934 --> 00:08:15.334
I've got a lot of black market stuff and
things like that, that I've tested and

00:08:15.334 --> 00:08:15.960
put on there.

135
00:08:15.960 --> 00:08:20.999
I'm at the point now, because it's so

136
00:08:20.999 --> 00:08:25.683
I've developed my own stuff on top of
it because it opens up so many things.

137
00:08:25.683 --> 00:08:26.390
So, kind of neat stuff.

138
00:08:26.390 --> 00:08:29.215
Guess I shouldn't have told people
I'm developing my own stuff.

139
00:08:29.215 --> 00:08:30.640
>> [LAUGH]
>> Gonna have a weapon now.

140
00:08:30.640 --> 00:08:31.895
I'm gonna get stopped at the airport.

141
00:08:31.895 --> 00:08:34.660
>> [LAUGH] Ben asked a question
out there in the chat room.

142
00:08:34.660 --> 00:08:37.410
He asked,
do you find it any more difficult

00:08:37.410 --> 00:08:39.760
not having a full sized
keyboard working with that?

00:08:41.390 --> 00:08:45.890
>> [LAUGH] That's such a great question.

145
00:08:45.890 --> 00:08:51.800
It all depends on how comfortable
you are with a touch screen.

146
00:08:51.800 --> 00:08:58.490
For me, for someone grabbing my
cellphone and opening this thing up.

147
00:08:58.490 --> 00:09:04.771
I'm okay by going through and typing on
these small little keyboards that come up.

148
00:09:04.771 --> 00:09:09.464
I'm getting better at it, but if you're
something that's been cursed with fat

149
00:09:09.464 --> 00:09:14.381
fingers or something like that, that's
not meant to be derogatory, so calm down.

150
00:09:14.381 --> 00:09:17.456
>> I can see where the GUI might be pretty
easy but some of those command line

151
00:09:17.456 --> 00:09:20.136
utilities where you really gotta
type commands in and stuff.

152
00:09:20.136 --> 00:09:24.907
>> That could be, the keyboard will
still remain the same size, but

153
00:09:24.907 --> 00:09:28.051
the command lines might be a little small.

154
00:09:28.051 --> 00:09:30.870
But fortunately, you can adjust
the text on a lot of these things.

155
00:09:30.870 --> 00:09:33.800
Now, if you're trying to do it
on a device like this, yeah,

156
00:09:33.800 --> 00:09:38.340
it's gonna be like whoa,
what's going on there?

157
00:09:38.340 --> 00:09:42.780
If you're on something like a tablet,
you have more screen real estate so

158
00:09:42.780 --> 00:09:44.510
it becomes a little bit easier.

159
00:09:44.510 --> 00:09:50.840
So I guess the thing in here is,
is it tough doing it?

160
00:09:50.840 --> 00:09:51.530
Yes and no.

161
00:09:51.530 --> 00:09:55.029
If you're pretty good at texting on
a keyboard and going through and

162
00:09:56.260 --> 00:10:00.080
doing stuff that way,
then hey, if you can do that,

163
00:10:00.080 --> 00:10:05.640
your kung fu type stuff on that
keyboard back and forth, go for it!

164
00:10:05.640 --> 00:10:07.500
You're probably just fine.

165
00:10:07.500 --> 00:10:11.190
If you're not, then you may want
to consider getting a larger

166
00:10:11.190 --> 00:10:14.190
device like a tablet that
has more screen real estate,

167
00:10:14.190 --> 00:10:16.879
thus bigger buttons on there
makes it easier for you.

168
00:10:18.600 --> 00:10:21.716
And then I saw on here it says
get a Bluetooth keyboard but

169
00:10:21.716 --> 00:10:25.313
then like it was noted on here,
you're back to having a laptop.

170
00:10:25.313 --> 00:10:28.706
I had that option with my Nexus
tablets of getting a keyboard and

171
00:10:28.706 --> 00:10:33.266
I was this close to getting one, and I'm
like, no, that just defeats the purpose.

172
00:10:33.266 --> 00:10:37.691
If I want a keyboard on something, then
yeah, I'll just carry this around with me.

173
00:10:37.691 --> 00:10:41.805
I didn't want to do that, so I got used
to doing it with this type of stuff.

174
00:10:41.805 --> 00:10:45.240
So, you'll figure out a way to adapt for
it.

175
00:10:45.240 --> 00:10:46.919
It's not going to be the same experience.

176
00:10:46.919 --> 00:10:48.591
I'll tell you that right away.

177
00:10:48.591 --> 00:10:52.068
>> All right, and then tool wise,
I think you mentioned not all of the tools

178
00:10:52.068 --> 00:10:55.950
are available in NetHunter that we
see in the full install of Kali.

179
00:10:55.950 --> 00:10:59.140
>> Yeah, it's not everything's
going to be over there.

180
00:10:59.140 --> 00:11:03.840
There's going to be a lot of things
that do come over, but not all of them.

181
00:11:03.840 --> 00:11:07.530
Don't expect things like
vulnerability scanners to come over.

182
00:11:07.530 --> 00:11:11.210
So things like OpenVas and Nexus,
those aren't going to come over.

183
00:11:11.210 --> 00:11:14.630
Even though, you go in
the Google Play store, it says heck,

184
00:11:14.630 --> 00:11:18.880
you could install Nexus
on your Android platform.

185
00:11:19.890 --> 00:11:22.460
That's basically a line
of crap cuz what that is,

186
00:11:22.460 --> 00:11:25.840
what they're doing is they're saying,
hey, we're installing the Nexus client.

187
00:11:25.840 --> 00:11:29.330
You still have to have APC or something in
some place else that you're terminaling

188
00:11:29.330 --> 00:11:32.840
into and connecting to to run
the vulnerability scan over there.

189
00:11:32.840 --> 00:11:36.080
To me, that runs counter to what
I'm trying to accomplish here.

190
00:11:36.080 --> 00:11:38.840
I want something that's
completely self-contained and

191
00:11:38.840 --> 00:11:40.280
doesn't arouse any suspicion.

192
00:11:40.280 --> 00:11:43.970
And I may be some place where I
need to be completely off the grid,

193
00:11:43.970 --> 00:11:47.480
that when I did this thing,
when I built this thing the way it is,

194
00:11:47.480 --> 00:11:52.720
I wanted to limit as much as I
could any external connections.

195
00:11:52.720 --> 00:11:55.890
I wanted to be able to keep this
thing up to date and then boom.

196
00:11:55.890 --> 00:11:56.630
Got it.

197
00:11:56.630 --> 00:11:58.870
So tools.

198
00:11:58.870 --> 00:12:03.440
Just because it's Android,
there's so many tools out there.

199
00:12:03.440 --> 00:12:10.077
The question is is just, how far are you
willing to take this, would be the thing.

200
00:12:10.077 --> 00:12:11.771
You can take this pretty far.

201
00:12:11.771 --> 00:12:16.750
And the reason why I'm kind of saying how
willing are you is that first of all,

202
00:12:16.750 --> 00:12:18.902
you've got to invest your time.

203
00:12:18.902 --> 00:12:22.425
I do this for a living, so I'm willing
to do the research and checks and

204
00:12:22.425 --> 00:12:23.400
everything on it.

205
00:12:23.400 --> 00:12:27.756
But the other thing I kind of have on
this, when I'm doing something like this,

206
00:12:27.756 --> 00:12:32.258
is that a lot of those tools, you're not
gonna find them on the Google Play Store.

207
00:12:32.258 --> 00:12:35.182
So if you're someone that's saying,
hey, I want to do hacking,

208
00:12:35.182 --> 00:12:39.050
let me go into Google play and
type in hacking and see what comes up.

209
00:12:39.050 --> 00:12:41.280
This probably isn't the device for you.

210
00:12:41.280 --> 00:12:44.568
What you're going to need to do is
you're going to need to go out and

211
00:12:44.568 --> 00:12:48.583
Google and search for APKs and stuff,
which APK is a little installation thing.

212
00:12:48.583 --> 00:12:52.226
And the APKs that are not on the Google
Play Store, if you try to install them,

213
00:12:52.226 --> 00:12:55.984
it's going to freak out and it'll say
whoa, this came from an unknown source,

214
00:12:55.984 --> 00:12:58.197
I don't know who this is and
everything else.

215
00:12:58.197 --> 00:13:01.307
You're just gonna have
to take a deep breath,

216
00:13:01.307 --> 00:13:06.690
turn off the safety features, and
install it and see what happens.

217
00:13:06.690 --> 00:13:07.670
That's what took me so

218
00:13:07.670 --> 00:13:11.900
long to get these devices set up is
I had to do a lot of testing on them.

219
00:13:11.900 --> 00:13:15.720
That's why I've got this device,
which I use every day for my calls.

220
00:13:15.720 --> 00:13:20.180
And then I have another one that I do my
testing on, to make sure that that one,

221
00:13:20.180 --> 00:13:23.090
any tools that I have in there that
are not beaming anything out that

222
00:13:23.090 --> 00:13:25.120
I don't want or anything like that.

223
00:13:25.120 --> 00:13:27.930
So, it does take a little a more work, but

224
00:13:27.930 --> 00:13:31.070
there already is a pretty
robust set of tools built in.

225
00:13:31.070 --> 00:13:33.680
So that's the good thing.

226
00:13:33.680 --> 00:13:36.210
>> And then,
as far as system requirements go,

227
00:13:36.210 --> 00:13:38.760
there are some limitations
we got to deal with?

228
00:13:38.760 --> 00:13:42.399
>> Yeah, there are some
limitations to this to be sure.

229
00:13:42.399 --> 00:13:47.973
In fact, I see in the discussion group
you've got Ben sitting over there and

00:13:47.973 --> 00:13:52.431
he's talking about something
called the Nokia N9000.

231
00:13:52.431 --> 00:13:54.509
That is an older device.

232
00:13:54.509 --> 00:13:57.880
I forget how old that thing is.

233
00:13:57.880 --> 00:14:04.780
But the Nokia, not N9000,
N900 that is a, the reason why

234
00:14:04.780 --> 00:14:08.550
you want to look at something like this
and let me see if I can bring it up here.

235
00:14:08.550 --> 00:14:11.310
Usually you are going to have
to look on Ebay or something.

236
00:14:11.310 --> 00:14:15.270
Yeah, I found, I believe this is
the N900 right here I have on my screen.

237
00:14:16.500 --> 00:14:21.720
This is the, and where this fits into
the whole hardware limitations is that

238
00:14:21.720 --> 00:14:25.955
something like this,
this has NFC, bluetooth and

239
00:14:25.955 --> 00:14:29.210
wi-fi in it in addition to
the normal cell phone functions.

240
00:14:30.370 --> 00:14:34.300
That's great, and you might,
just going into this you're like,

241
00:14:34.300 --> 00:14:37.570
hey it's got bluetooth and wi-fi,
you want to be able to do that.

242
00:14:37.570 --> 00:14:41.920
All the fun games that go with
cracking and hacking into wi-fi and

243
00:14:41.920 --> 00:14:46.950
messing with Bluetooth ain't gonna
happen with this because what you

244
00:14:46.950 --> 00:14:52.630
have to do is you have to get what they
call an OTG cable, a USB on the go cable.

245
00:14:52.630 --> 00:14:57.395
It plugs into your micro USB port and
then gives you a full-blown USB port.

246
00:14:57.395 --> 00:15:02.335
And what you'll do is you plug in
an external Bluetooth adapter or

247
00:15:02.335 --> 00:15:07.375
an external wi-fi adapter that has
the ability to do promiscuous mode,

248
00:15:07.375 --> 00:15:09.289
or in the case of Bluetooth, monitor mode.

249
00:15:10.740 --> 00:15:17.150
There's pretty much with some exceptions
very few cell phones that have the ability

250
00:15:17.150 --> 00:15:23.280
to do promiscuous mode with wi-fi,
and I haven't really seen any that can

251
00:15:23.280 --> 00:15:26.840
do any of the Bluetooth stuff other than
just do the pairings and associations.

252
00:15:26.840 --> 00:15:29.250
Hence, you gotta use an external adaptor.

253
00:15:29.250 --> 00:15:34.593
The Nokia N900 is an exception because it
breaks at least one of those limitations.

254
00:15:34.593 --> 00:15:39.428
The limitation on this one, or that it
breaks is that it can do promiscuous mode

255
00:15:39.428 --> 00:15:41.787
with its WiFi adaptor, internally.

256
00:15:41.787 --> 00:15:46.026
So you don't have to do that, but
you would still need to have something for

257
00:15:46.026 --> 00:15:48.870
Bluetooth if you want to
start messing with that.

258
00:15:48.870 --> 00:15:52.882
So these ones you should be able to
get if you do wanna go ahead and

259
00:15:52.882 --> 00:15:56.455
get one of these things,
they're not that expensive.

260
00:15:56.455 --> 00:16:00.790
There's one, it's 129 bucks on eBay.

261
00:16:00.790 --> 00:16:06.240
These things are not brand new, so you're
pretty much gonna be picking these things

262
00:16:06.240 --> 00:16:12.200
up used for the most part, but
if you want it, there you go.

263
00:16:12.200 --> 00:16:13.600
Now, yeah, there's talk,

00:16:13.600 --> 00:16:17.870
there's been some murmurs about
putting Kali NetHunter on this one.

00:16:17.870 --> 00:16:21.093
You can get the Pwnie Express,
the Pwn Phone stuff,

266
00:16:21.093 --> 00:16:24.220
you can get it to put
on there already today.

00:16:24.220 --> 00:16:28.450
And we'll talk about that another day,
too, so that's not off the hook either,

268
00:16:28.450 --> 00:16:30.500
we're just talking about Kali right now.

269

So, there are some hardware limitations,
and typically the hardware limitations

270

with the bluetooth side of things.

271
00:16:41.192 --> 00:16:44.350

right now, is to kinda give you

And because we have such

what I want to do is

In fact, first of all, if you look on my

The reason why I'm not showing it

00:17:46.260 --> 00:17:48.471

00:17:48.471 --> 00:17:50.386
So you're really gonna

But what you have here, this is

00:17:55.331 --> 00:17:58.283
If you open it up on one
of these Nexus devices,

you'll get the exact same

00:18:01.552 --> 00:18:03.712
It's all touchscreen.

00:18:03.712 --> 00:18:06.853
Anyone that's running an Android device

00:18:06.853 --> 00:18:08.620
I know how to get around that no problem.

00:18:08.620 --> 00:18:13.370
I see that little row of dots there in the
middle on the right-hand side, click that,

00:18:13.370 --> 00:18:15.660
that shows me the main application page.

297
00:18:15.660 --> 00:18:18.300
So simple like that.

298
00:18:18.300 --> 00:18:21.340
I think even if I unlock device in here.

299
00:18:21.340 --> 00:18:26.660
So what I'm gonna show here
is this is my device and

300
00:18:26.660 --> 00:18:28.000
we'll give you a closer look at it.

301
00:18:28.000 --> 00:18:31.130
This is just to give you a quick overview
cuz we are gonna be working more closely

302
00:18:31.130 --> 00:18:32.000
with Kali NetHunter.

303
00:18:32.000 --> 00:18:34.522
So don't sit there and

304
00:18:34.522 --> 00:18:37.280
>> [LAUGH]
>> Get some glasses, eat some carrots.

305
00:18:37.280 --> 00:18:40.620
All right, so you can see it looks
like a typical Android device.

306
00:18:40.620 --> 00:18:42.390
I can hit the little dots at the bottom.

307
00:18:42.390 --> 00:18:47.000
And I have you know trays, or
I have pages and pages of applications.

308
00:18:47.000 --> 00:18:50.400
And, yes, most of these are used for
pen testing and security work and

00:18:50.400 --> 00:18:51.500
stuff like that.

310
00:18:51.500 --> 00:18:52.225
Security work.

311
00:18:52.225 --> 00:18:54.417
>> [LAUGH]
>> I call it stalking.

00:18:54.417 --> 00:18:56.630
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, but yeah you've got pages and

00:18:56.630 --> 00:19:00.600

It works and acts just like

that's the really neat thing in there.

Yes, there are some things that when

And that's where we're gonna wanna start

But it's a familiar experience,

You know that's probably

But the NetHunter interface, the really

there's really not much to learn

It kinda does change the game a little

00:20:18.620 --> 00:20:22.310

And running something like Kali NetHunter,

>> [LAUGH]
>> Now you've really gotta be careful and

00:20:35.930 --> 00:20:40.420
>> Yeah, you can't be asleep at

00:20:40.420 --> 00:20:43.930
With these types of devices,

00:20:43.930 --> 00:20:48.590
I've modified this enough that I

00:20:48.590 --> 00:20:52.120

00:20:52.120 --> 00:20:54.350
It will show up like just

00:20:54.350 --> 00:21:00.160
And it's got multiple distros of Linux

351
00:21:00.160 --> 00:21:07.600
So I've got a customized distro of

00:21:07.600 --> 00:21:11.249
So all I gotta do is go to your

00:21:11.249 --> 00:21:15.610

00:21:15.610 --> 00:21:20.430
Plug it in, pop it in, and

00:21:20.430 --> 00:21:24.670
Load that ISO file, and
let the games begin, you can do that.

356
00:21:24.670 --> 00:21:30.270
I can load full-blown Kali off of this and

357
00:21:30.270 --> 00:21:34.670
I can run a boot to, heck if I want to,
the possibilities there.

I can run a copy of Windows,

I could create a bootable copy of

00:21:40.344 --> 00:21:41.810
>> [LAUGH]
>> I would never torture my

00:21:41.810 --> 00:21:46.020
device like that, but
you could definitely do that.

00:21:46.020 --> 00:21:51.630
So, it leads to some extremely

00:21:51.630 --> 00:21:56.100

As far as putting it on devices,

One of the big things that you're

Loading stock Kali,

Boot off this, and

But you can't do that the same

There's things that have to happen,

No matter what Android device you have,

So we're gonna avoid that by

00:23:18.672 --> 00:23:19.460
[LAUGH].

>> I'm a Shaolin monk on the weekends.

00:23:20.724 --> 00:23:21.290
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

00:23:21.290 --> 00:23:23.241
>> All right, well, Sean,

392
00:23:25.290 --> 00:23:30.110
Looking forward to seeing both Kali and

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike demonstrate installing Kali 2.0. They talk about the different installation and upgrade options. Then they install Kali 2.0 in a virtual machine.
episodes.title: Installing and Upgrading Kali 2.0
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.446
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.446 --> 00:00:12.581
Hello and
welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:12.581 --> 00:00:17.000
I'm your host Mike Rodrick, and
with me today is Mr. Sean Oriyano.

4
00:00:17.000 --> 00:00:21.380
And in this episode, Sean, we're gonna
be taking a look at installing Kali.

5
00:00:21.380 --> 00:00:25.180
We've talked about the new
version of Kali that's out, 2.0,

6
00:00:25.180 --> 00:00:28.580
talked a little bit about Kali NetHunter.

7
00:00:28.580 --> 00:00:32.660
Now we wanna go back, focus on Kali 2.0,
and take a look at the different ways we

8
00:00:32.660 --> 00:00:34.960
can install it, and
actually do an installation for you.

9
00:00:34.960 --> 00:00:37.640
So Sean, show us how we do it.

10
00:00:37.640 --> 00:00:42.200
>> All right, so what we're gonna do
here is we're gonna install Kali 2.0.

11
00:00:42.200 --> 00:00:45.079
And we're gonna be installing
into a virtual environment,

12
00:00:45.079 --> 00:00:47.061
this virtual environment being VMware.

13
00:00:47.061 --> 00:00:53.520
But you can choose your weapon of choice,
whatever that might be for virtualization.

14
00:00:53.520 --> 00:00:57.520
So the idea here is to get
it into that environment.

15
00:00:57.520 --> 00:01:01.190
Now, just for the record, this is mainly
to show you what the installation

16
00:01:01.190 --> 00:01:04.970
process looks like, and
also discuss some of the issues.

17
00:01:04.970 --> 00:01:08.023
If you really, truly want a virtual
image and run it that way,

18
00:01:08.023 --> 00:01:10.571
there's even an easier way
to get a virtual image.

19
00:01:10.571 --> 00:01:14.790
And that's just to download a virtual
image from the offensive security site for

20
00:01:14.790 --> 00:01:16.710
Kali and you're ready to go.

21
00:01:16.710 --> 00:01:21.890
But we're gonna use this as more of
a demo of how to do the installation,

22
00:01:21.890 --> 00:01:27.570
rather than we're gonna focus on
something as, hey we're specifically

23
00:01:27.570 --> 00:01:31.520
creating a virtual image for the purpose
of creating a virtual image for later.

24
00:01:31.520 --> 00:01:36.710
So, the way things are gonna work is I
have already downloaded the ISO file for

25
00:01:36.710 --> 00:01:37.920
us of Kali 2.0.

26
00:01:37.920 --> 00:01:42.280
I downloaded it before we got
started today to make sure I had

27
00:01:42.280 --> 00:01:44.740
the freshest of the fresh.

28
00:01:44.740 --> 00:01:45.759
So I've got that.

29
00:01:47.170 --> 00:01:54.720
And what I've done here on my computer is
I have set it up so I have VMware running.

30
00:01:54.720 --> 00:01:56.120
So you can see I have VMware and

31
00:01:56.120 --> 00:01:59.370
I'm going through the process of
creating a new virtual machine.

32
00:01:59.370 --> 00:02:01.310
When I create a new virtual machine,

33
00:02:01.310 --> 00:02:07.380
what's gonna happen is I'm
gonna choose my Kali ISO file.

34
00:02:07.380 --> 00:02:10.049
Click Next,
it asks me what operating system it is.

35

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike look at building a custom image for installing Kali Linux. They start by setting up the live-build system. Sean then describes the process of adding packages for your custom build.
episodes.title: Creating a Custom Kali Image

You can get in Kali since they

You could have one script running

216

doing this the first time because when you
look through it you may actually see some

217
00:12:47.720 --> 00:12:49.140
errors pop up.

218
00:12:49.140 --> 00:12:51.410
And then at the end you
see the process fail.

219
00:12:51.410 --> 00:12:54.210
Well, what you can do is you can scroll
up through that list and say okay,

220
00:12:54.210 --> 00:12:55.180
what was it missing?

221
00:12:55.180 --> 00:12:58.080
Oh, these are the actual
libraries it's missing.

222
00:12:58.080 --> 00:13:00.970
I can go get those and
you can bring those in.

223
00:13:00.970 --> 00:13:04.210
And so, once you got that,
got all those things resolved and

224
00:13:04.210 --> 00:13:07.140
then run live build again,
then you should have a point where hey,

225
00:13:07.140 --> 00:13:10.600
everything is all ready and completed.

226
00:13:10.600 --> 00:13:13.120
So that's right there what you're seeing,

227
00:13:13.120 --> 00:13:15.710
that's the actual live build
process going through.

228
00:13:15.710 --> 00:13:20.130
And that does take some time depending
on the system and the resources and

229
00:13:20.130 --> 00:13:21.470
all that available.

230
00:13:21.470 --> 00:13:25.430
But while that's doing its thing, and
we'll say at this point all you have to do

231
00:13:25.430 --> 00:13:28.260
is just pick up the ISO file at
the end like I was telling, is you

232
00:13:28.260 --> 00:13:32.240
just go into the build folder, there's
my ISO file, grab it, copy it, done.

233
00:13:32.240 --> 00:13:33.430
It's all you need to do.

234
00:13:33.430 --> 00:13:37.920
So let's talk about
the idea of customizing.

235
00:13:37.920 --> 00:13:44.430
So if you need to customize this,
this is again on the Kali doc site.

236
00:13:44.430 --> 00:13:45.971
The awesomeness of live build.

237
00:13:45.971 --> 00:13:46.720
>> [LAUGH] I love it.

238
00:13:46.720 --> 00:13:49.350
>> So
you know it's good when they say that.

239
00:13:49.350 --> 00:13:51.550
So we got the awesomeness of live build.

240
00:13:51.550 --> 00:13:54.350
What we have here is they're

241
00:13:54.350 --> 00:13:58.170
showing you just an idea here
of how you customize this.

242
00:13:58.170 --> 00:14:03.500
What this is doing here is this person
just added in, hey we want to install some

243
00:14:03.500 --> 00:14:07.910
other stuff so they created this file and
they told it, these are the things they

244
00:14:07.910 --> 00:14:13.080
want to have installed, open SSH server,
and some sound tools and some other stuff.

245
00:14:13.080 --> 00:14:16.380
They just went through and
Ran that script, and

246
00:14:16.380 --> 00:14:20.090
it's gonna tell when they create this
script, what's gonna happen is is that

247
00:14:20.090 --> 00:14:23.680
it's gonna go ahead and
start installing these during the process.

248
00:14:23.680 --> 00:14:30.270
So these aren't here by default,
the packages are are not here by default.

249
00:14:30.270 --> 00:14:35.150
They just created a script, they dump
it into a folder in there and the live

250
00:14:35.150 --> 00:14:38.330
build process, when it sees that script
will go, oh hey there's another one,

251
00:14:38.330 --> 00:14:41.560
and grab it and it will start running
that and downloading those tools too.

252
00:14:43.220 --> 00:14:46.080
It's actually quite neat
to be able to do that.

253
00:14:46.080 --> 00:14:47.740
And you can go even further,

254
00:14:47.740 --> 00:14:51.850
they're showing here on their site that
if you really wanted to go to town.

255
00:14:51.850 --> 00:14:54.470
You wanna change the wallpaper.

256
00:14:54.470 --> 00:15:00.080
There's changing the whole process,
change the wallpaper, if you want.

257
00:15:00.080 --> 00:15:03.800
If you don't like that dragon image,
you can do that.

258
00:15:03.800 --> 00:15:06.230
You wanna install other packages,

259
00:15:06.230 --> 00:15:10.330
this is the one that I'd say you're
really interested in right here.

260
00:15:10.330 --> 00:15:14.300
They're using as an example.

261
00:15:14.300 --> 00:15:20.170
All you have to do is underneath the live
build folder, so you saw the live

262
00:15:20.170 --> 00:15:23.430
build folder with all the scripts there,
the build scripts and everything in there?

263
00:15:23.430 --> 00:15:27.620
All you have to do is make a directory,
call config for

264
00:15:27.620 --> 00:15:32.100
packages and then just dump
your deviant files in there.

265
00:15:32.100 --> 00:15:33.080
Once you've done that,

266
00:15:33.080 --> 00:15:36.910
all those things will get installed
during the live build process.

267
00:15:36.910 --> 00:15:38.990
So, that's pretty cool.

268
00:15:38.990 --> 00:15:42.060
Once you've done that and you're happy,
all you've gotta do is run live build and

269
00:15:42.060 --> 00:15:43.680
let the thing rock and roll.

270
00:15:43.680 --> 00:15:46.930
And it will just go ahead and
crank out the image.

271
00:15:46.930 --> 00:15:50.720
Like I said, expect the image to take
some period of time to build, but

272
00:15:50.720 --> 00:15:54.140
you may have to do some
troubleshooting the first time or so.

273
00:15:54.140 --> 00:15:58.380
After that, it should be able
to just cruise right on through.

274
00:15:58.380 --> 00:16:02.831
And to give you some ideas of some of the
things they've done, they ran a script,

275
00:16:02.831 --> 00:16:05.580
they were showing you
a little script in there with

276
00:16:05.580 --> 00:16:08.470
tools they have Look at some
other things you can do.

277
00:16:08.470 --> 00:16:09.776
This right here.

278
00:16:09.776 --> 00:16:14.500
Hey you want to change Kali so
it is not using the gnome interface.

279
00:16:14.500 --> 00:16:16.800
You know those pull downs and
stuff that we have.

280
00:16:16.800 --> 00:16:21.150
You could actually tell it to use KDE
which is a more Windows like interface.

281
00:16:21.150 --> 00:16:25.040
All you have to do is
just tell it build SH.

282
00:16:25.040 --> 00:16:27.500
Tell it you want to take
the the Kali distribution,

283
00:16:27.500 --> 00:16:31.870
the Sauna distribution, tell it you
want to run the variant KDE, so

284
00:16:31.870 --> 00:16:35.250
you want to switch it over to
a KDE environment, and that's it!

285
00:16:35.250 --> 00:16:36.191
That's all you need to do.

286
00:16:36.191 --> 00:16:42.220
The [INAUDIBLE] of course just tells
us what's going on during the process.

287
00:16:42.220 --> 00:16:45.400
So you could actually just change the
interface if you don't like the interface,

288
00:16:45.400 --> 00:16:46.700
change it.

289
00:16:46.700 --> 00:16:50.843
So it's a pretty powerful tool to have.

290
00:16:50.843 --> 00:16:54.222
So what you're gonna have to do to
make the whole thing work, though,

291
00:16:54.222 --> 00:16:56.056
is you're gonna have to go through and

292
00:16:56.056 --> 00:16:59.300
do that initial thing of
downloading the live build files.

293
00:16:59.300 --> 00:17:03.090
And bringing those onto the system and
then compiling those and

294
00:17:03.090 --> 00:17:07.090
getting those to work and
then debugging it if any errors pop up.

295
00:17:07.090 --> 00:17:09.270
Like I said they probably will but

296
00:17:09.270 --> 00:17:11.880
when those errors pop up they're
usually easily resolvable.

297
00:17:11.880 --> 00:17:15.980
If you see a library or
something, a library or

298
00:17:15.980 --> 00:17:20.020
something comes up and says, well,
this isn't the right version.

299
00:17:20.020 --> 00:17:20.920
I had that happen.

300
00:17:20.920 --> 00:17:23.810
I had that when I was doing this,
this morning doing the set up for it.

301
00:17:23.810 --> 00:17:26.500
It said, oh, this library isn't present.

302
00:17:26.500 --> 00:17:28.730
Well, I looked at it,
that library was present.

303
00:17:28.730 --> 00:17:32.600
What happened was the library it wanted
was a customized version for Kali so

304
00:17:32.600 --> 00:17:35.570
now I had to go out and
grab the one for and drop it in there.

305
00:17:35.570 --> 00:17:38.790
Then all of a sudden it was happy.

306
00:17:38.790 --> 00:17:42.610
You know so you kind of got to be
prepared to look at some of these,

307
00:17:42.610 --> 00:17:43.990
look at some of these things.

308
00:17:43.990 --> 00:17:48.120
If you're missing, missing libraries
one of the easiest things to do,

309
00:17:48.120 --> 00:17:51.490
to try is you should be able
to write the command line.

310
00:17:51.490 --> 00:17:56.230
Use the command at-get and
then space, install and then space,

311
00:17:56.230 --> 00:17:57.860
the name of the library.

312
00:17:57.860 --> 00:18:01.620
And what that will you do is if you're
missing it and Kali actually has it and

313
00:18:01.620 --> 00:18:05.190
it is repository someplace it
will bring the stuff down and

314
00:18:05.190 --> 00:18:08.150
put it onto the system and go from there.

315
00:18:09.150 --> 00:18:10.810
>> Are the packages pretty easily to find,

316
00:18:10.810 --> 00:18:12.450
like the Nexus packages and
things like that?

317
00:18:12.450 --> 00:18:17.550
Do we have to get them from Kali or
can we get them from anywhere?

318
00:18:17.550 --> 00:18:19.680
>> No, you won't get them from Kali.

319
00:18:19.680 --> 00:18:24.860
If it's something that's in Kali by
default then you would go through and

320
00:18:24.860 --> 00:18:28.320
just create that script and
say grab these ones and it would know.

321
00:18:28.320 --> 00:18:29.690
Oh yeah.
I have to run the at-get

322
00:18:29.690 --> 00:18:30.440
command, to do that.

323
00:18:30.440 --> 00:18:34.370
Because it knows, by the fact that those
are present and in the correct order,

324
00:18:34.370 --> 00:18:36.190
this is where it's gonna get it from.

325
00:18:36.190 --> 00:18:41.550
If it's something that isn't part of Kali,
like Nexus wouldn't be there.

326
00:18:41.550 --> 00:18:46.770
Well then what you'd have to do is go
to a site, download the Debian file and

327
00:18:46.770 --> 00:18:51.110
put it in the folder we talked about
here and then it would pick it up.

328
00:18:51.110 --> 00:18:54.000
>> So the vendor that makes the product
you're trying to add to your custom image,

329
00:18:54.000 --> 00:18:56.140
they would supply the dev file.

330
00:18:56.140 --> 00:18:57.580
>> Yeah think of it
the same way you would for

331
00:18:57.580 --> 00:19:00.880
Windows, if you wanna install
like Wireshark into Windows.

332
00:19:00.880 --> 00:19:02.080
It's not there by default.

333
00:19:02.080 --> 00:19:03.230
So, what do you do, you go to their site.

334
00:19:03.230 --> 00:19:04.170
Click on it.
Download it.

335
00:19:04.170 --> 00:19:04.900
It's executable.

336
00:19:04.900 --> 00:19:06.120
Same process.

337
00:19:06.120 --> 00:19:06.680
>> Very good.

338
00:19:06.680 --> 00:19:07.630
Very good.

339
00:19:07.630 --> 00:19:09.590
>> All right Sean,
well that is great information.

340
00:19:09.590 --> 00:19:13.310
Now, we can take our Kali imaging and
customize it our heart's content.

341
00:19:13.310 --> 00:19:14.000
We can add things.

342
00:19:14.000 --> 00:19:14.800
We can move things.

343
00:19:14.800 --> 00:19:17.140
We can change default environment.

344
00:19:17.140 --> 00:19:19.200
We can change the interface.

345
00:19:19.200 --> 00:19:20.480
I mean, you name.

346
00:19:20.480 --> 00:19:23.510
If we spend the time, we can change it.

347
00:19:23.510 --> 00:19:25.610
And that's just gonna make
it more efficient, right.

348
00:19:25.610 --> 00:19:27.760
If I can get rid of
the things I don't need,

349
00:19:27.760 --> 00:19:32.370
add the things that I do need, that just
makes it a better operating in the end.

350
00:19:32.370 --> 00:19:34.220
Or more useful to me, right?

351
00:19:34.220 --> 00:19:35.430
>> It absolutely does.

352
00:19:35.430 --> 00:19:40.770
Having the power to take a tool that's
really, in essence, a one-size-fits-all.

353
00:19:40.770 --> 00:19:44.730
And I'm not trying to talk
bad about Kali or anything.

354
00:19:44.730 --> 00:19:46.900
I'm just saying it's
a one-size-fits-all tool.

355
00:19:46.900 --> 00:19:48.920
What you see is what you get.

356
00:19:48.920 --> 00:19:50.830
You download this tool.

357
00:19:50.830 --> 00:19:55.050
I download that tool, Mike downloads that
tool, we're all getting the same thing.

358
00:19:55.050 --> 00:19:56.710
But why not customize it?

359
00:19:56.710 --> 00:19:59.540
Why not make it more to your liking?

360
00:19:59.540 --> 00:20:03.930
And I wouldn't recommend that you just
all of a sudden download Kali and say,

361
00:20:03.930 --> 00:20:04.650
you know what?

362
00:20:04.650 --> 00:20:08.530
I'm gonna live build stuff because I
don't like the default environment.

363
00:20:08.530 --> 00:20:09.710
What don't you like about it?

364
00:20:09.710 --> 00:20:12.960
Get utilities, try things out,
see what you customize.

365
00:20:12.960 --> 00:20:16.250
Once you've got the environment
that you feel comfortable with and

366
00:20:16.250 --> 00:20:19.130
you like, then use Live Build to say,

367
00:20:19.130 --> 00:20:24.050
yeah okay I want to recreate that
environment and make my own ISO out of it.

368
00:20:24.050 --> 00:20:26.940
And once you have your own ISO then
you can just drop it on systems.

369
00:20:26.940 --> 00:20:28.250
Wherever you want.

370
00:20:28.250 --> 00:20:31.280
And heck, if you really want to do it,
you can fully script it out, so

371
00:20:31.280 --> 00:20:33.910
all you gotta do is drop
it in your CD drive or

372
00:20:33.910 --> 00:20:38.470
plug it into your flash drive, boot off
of it, hit enter and just walk away.

373
00:20:38.470 --> 00:20:42.190
When you come back, you'll have
Kali with your user accounts and

374
00:20:42.190 --> 00:20:45.590
everything else created and
ready to go and to be used.

375
00:20:45.590 --> 00:20:49.610
>> All right ladies and gentlemen
another fantastic episode with Kali 2.0.

376
00:20:49.610 --> 00:20:50.930
That's gonna do it for this one.

377
00:20:50.930 --> 00:20:52.320
Signing off for ITProTV.

378
00:20:52.320 --> 00:20:53.750
I'm Mike Rodrick.

379
00:20:53.750 --> 00:20:54.820
>> And I'm Sean Oriyano.

380
00:20:54.820 --> 00:20:56.628
>> And we'll see you next time.

381
00:20:56.628 --> 00:20:57.128
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Don look at running Kali Linux in forensics mode. They demonstrate how to launch Kali Linux in forensics mode. They also discuss the advantages of running Kali in forensics mode.
episodes.title: Forensics Mode
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.504
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.504 --> 00:00:12.901
All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening.

3
00:00:12.901 --> 00:00:15.314
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.314 --> 00:00:19.935
I'm your host Don Pezet, back again
with another episode of ITProTV and

5
00:00:19.935 --> 00:00:22.372
ready to jump into Kali Linux 2.0.

6
00:00:22.372 --> 00:00:24.700
Sean, what's on the table for us today?

7
00:00:24.700 --> 00:00:27.530
>> Well, what we're gonna be looking
at today, is we're gonna be looking at

8
00:00:27.530 --> 00:00:32.370
another mode of Kali that we really
haven't seen before in the other shows.

9
00:00:32.370 --> 00:00:36.886
So that's kind of exciting, really, so
feel free to get excited about that.

10
00:00:36.886 --> 00:00:40.151
>> [LAUGH]
>> What we're looking at is we're gonna be

11
00:00:40.151 --> 00:00:42.108
looking at forensics mode and

12
00:00:42.108 --> 00:00:46.820
seeing what that offers to us over
the normal modes that Kali offers us.

13
00:00:46.820 --> 00:00:48.940
Cuz we've talked about live mode,

14
00:00:50.050 --> 00:00:54.790
the persistence with running it off USB,
we've done all that.

15
00:00:54.790 --> 00:00:58.250
Well, let's see what forensics
mode will do for us.

16
00:00:58.250 --> 00:01:01.640
And what we wanna do is we wanna
start that off by, first of all,

17
00:01:01.640 --> 00:01:04.300
why are you gonna use forensics mode.

18
00:01:04.300 --> 00:01:07.280
Forensics mode, well, I guess
the name kind of says itself, right?

19
00:01:07.280 --> 00:01:09.955
[LAUGH] You're looking for evidence.

20
00:01:09.955 --> 00:01:14.485
So, forensics mode is the special
mode of Kali Linux that

21
00:01:14.485 --> 00:01:19.705
allows you to analyze a system and
collect evidence.

22
00:01:19.705 --> 00:01:22.995
To do it in a very structured and

23
00:01:22.995 --> 00:01:26.710
standardized way that will
stand up under scrutiny.

24
00:01:26.710 --> 00:01:30.303
So that means that we've got things
that can do memory forensics,

25
00:01:30.303 --> 00:01:34.729
things that can recover files, things that
can hash files, things that can do all

26
00:01:34.729 --> 00:01:39.390
sorts of neat stuff in addition to helping
us generate reports and stuff like that.

27
00:01:39.390 --> 00:01:42.760
So there's some really,
really neat stuff here.

28
00:01:42.760 --> 00:01:44.490
But the first thing we've gotta look at,

29
00:01:44.490 --> 00:01:48.880
is once we know why we use it,
is we gotta figure out how to get into it.

30
00:01:48.880 --> 00:01:52.420
Because it's not a matter of just
starting it up and saying, oh,

31
00:01:52.420 --> 00:01:53.680
we're in forensics mode.

32
00:01:53.680 --> 00:01:56.100
No, no,
you gotta do a little more than that.

33
00:01:56.100 --> 00:02:02.910
So, what I have here on my screen is,
I have brought up inside of VMware.

34
00:02:02.910 --> 00:02:06.324
Typically you're not going to do
this inside a virtual machine.

35
00:02:06.324 --> 00:02:10.422
You're gonna run this off a flash drive,
to be quite honest.

36
00:02:10.422 --> 00:02:13.647
But just to make it easy to demo here and
all that is,

37
00:02:13.647 --> 00:02:16.366
we're doing it inside a virtual machine.

38
00:02:16.366 --> 00:02:19.309
So what I have here is I have,

39
00:02:19.309 --> 00:02:24.841
when I just loaded in my ISO file,
booted up off of it.

40
00:02:24.841 --> 00:02:28.788
And I have forensics mode sitting
there highlighted and ready to go.

41
00:02:28.788 --> 00:02:31.064
So you just choose it off the list.

42
00:02:31.064 --> 00:02:32.483
Notice it does say live,

43
00:02:32.483 --> 00:02:37.225
so it's telling us right away that
it's loading this right into memory.

44
00:02:37.225 --> 00:02:40.455
So it's not installing
anything to the system.

45
00:02:40.455 --> 00:02:44.975
And do remember that [LAUGH] you don't
wanna touch the system, that's the thing.

46
00:02:44.975 --> 00:02:46.615
Presumably if you're doing this,

47
00:02:46.615 --> 00:02:49.303
you've got a system that you
need to do investigation on.

48
00:02:49.303 --> 00:02:54.326
It's powered off and
you're just gonna go in,

49
00:02:54.326 --> 00:02:57.221
load this in through a USB.

50
00:02:57.221 --> 00:03:01.944
Or you're going to put a CD
in the drive or a DVD,

51
00:03:01.944 --> 00:03:05.382
what have you, and boot off of it.

52
00:03:05.382 --> 00:03:08.482
And, so that's what we're doing,
that's what we're kind of emulating here.

53
00:03:08.482 --> 00:03:12.431
So I'm just gonna go ahead,
I've highlighted it,

54
00:03:12.431 --> 00:03:14.600
it starts the load process.

55
00:03:14.600 --> 00:03:19.197
And it'll take a moment or two cuz it
has to get all that good stuff and

56
00:03:19.197 --> 00:03:20.579
put it into memory.

57
00:03:20.579 --> 00:03:24.120
And so
we can expect it to take a moment or two.

58
00:03:24.120 --> 00:03:26.050
>> Now Sean,
let me ask a question real quick.

59
00:03:26.050 --> 00:03:27.685
If I had booted in a normal mode,

60
00:03:27.685 --> 00:03:30.787
would I still have access to
the same tools in forensic mode?

61
00:03:30.787 --> 00:03:33.320
Or are there tools that are just
available in forensic mode?

00:25:50.690 --> 00:25:52.850
you can see the tremendous
amount of power,

461
00:25:52.850 --> 00:25:57.450
even though I had four lines of commands,
I could've kept going on and put 100, 200,

462
00:25:57.450 --> 00:26:01.410
300 commands in there, and let it go and
just walked away and let it do its thing.

463
00:26:01.410 --> 00:26:05.050
And it kept scanning, and scanning,
and scanning, and logging all that and

464
00:26:05.050 --> 00:26:06.750
going right on through.

465
00:26:06.750 --> 00:26:11.450
So there are some really
great things to do here, and

466
00:26:11.450 --> 00:26:15.260
just the fact that you don't have to
invest much time to set it up at all.

467
00:26:15.260 --> 00:26:19.090
Probably the thing that's going to cause
you the biggest amount of time here

468
00:26:19.090 --> 00:26:23.150
is setting up that text file, and
that text file, if you plan it right,

469
00:26:23.150 --> 00:26:26.950
you only really got to do that once.

470
00:26:26.950 --> 00:26:29.130
After you set it up,
you're just modifying it.

471
00:26:29.130 --> 00:26:31.060
>> Yeah,
that seems like the big advantage, really.

472
00:26:31.060 --> 00:26:34.330
It's not like you're distributing
the text file out to the clients,

473
00:26:34.330 --> 00:26:38.250
they're just calling home and getting
the file and running those commands,

474
00:26:38.250 --> 00:26:43.160
so you do that from one machine, you walk
over to another area, you grab another

475
00:26:43.160 --> 00:26:46.690
machine, you run the client, you tell
it to connect, it pulls down that file.

476
00:26:46.690 --> 00:26:50.170
So it's just saving you all
the time of running the individual

477
00:26:50.170 --> 00:26:52.550
N map commands on each
client that you go to.

478
00:26:52.550 --> 00:26:53.420
It's just saying,

479
00:26:53.420 --> 00:26:57.290
hey, go get this list, pull it down,
run those commands, basically.

480
00:26:57.290 --> 00:26:58.270
>> Yeah, absolutely.

481
00:26:58.270 --> 00:27:05.910
It's really, really simple as far as
it goes, I mean as far as tools go.

482
00:27:05.910 --> 00:27:08.342
N maps is doing the heavy lifting here.

483
00:27:08.342 --> 00:27:12.630
DN map is just spoon feeding
the commands back and forth, and

484
00:27:12.630 --> 00:27:18.780
there's really not much there to
do as far as that is concerned.

485
00:27:18.780 --> 00:27:22.070
You're still really doing
all the stuff in N map,

486
00:27:22.070 --> 00:27:23.740
instead of just typing
up the command line,

487
00:27:23.740 --> 00:27:27.970
now you're typing into a text file and so
you're still in the Nmap frame of mind.

488
00:27:27.970 --> 00:27:32.190
Once you've got that, hey, listen on this
port, use what's in this text file, and

489
00:27:32.190 --> 00:27:33.930
then start pointing stuff to it.

490
00:27:33.930 --> 00:27:39.010
A word of caution though, when you're
using this is both systems I was using

491
00:27:39.010 --> 00:27:45.040
here on mine are both Kali 2.0 systems,
they're both the full installations.

492
00:27:45.040 --> 00:27:49.790
One of the things that was mentioned
in a previous episode is that there is

493
00:27:49.790 --> 00:27:55.110
a full version of Kali, which I'm using,
there's also is a lite version of Kali.

494
00:27:55.110 --> 00:27:59.526
The full version's like
3.1 gigs to download, and

495
00:27:59.526 --> 00:28:02.317
the lite version was 0.8 gigs.

496
00:28:02.317 --> 00:28:05.540
So, you're losing something there,
somebody's been put on a major diet there.

497
00:28:05.540 --> 00:28:07.220
So, what are you losing?

498
00:28:07.220 --> 00:28:12.350
Well, the interface is different, like we
said, it's a little easier on resources.

499
00:28:12.350 --> 00:28:16.870
But, there's also some tools that
are stripped and one of them is dnmap.

500
00:28:16.870 --> 00:28:22.500
You can put dnmap over there because
there's nothing barring it from

501
00:28:22.500 --> 00:28:27.360
being installed there, it just means that
if you run one of these lite versions and

502
00:28:27.360 --> 00:28:30.200
you're like, where the heck did it go,
this should work, Kali 2 0.

503
00:28:30.200 --> 00:28:33.960
I was watching ITPro and
they said it was here, I watched it.

504
00:28:33.960 --> 00:28:36.340
Yes, but
it's not installed on the lite version.

505
00:28:36.340 --> 00:28:38.610
If you've got a full version, hey rock and

506
00:28:38.610 --> 00:28:42.320
roll man no extra work needed other
than what we showed you here.

507
00:28:42.320 --> 00:28:43.508
If you're using the lite version,

508
00:28:43.508 --> 00:28:48.220
you've got to install that first, and
then do the stuff that we showed you.

509
00:28:48.220 --> 00:28:48.830
>> Very good.
All right.

510
00:28:48.830 --> 00:28:52.160
Well Sean, another great episode,
a lot of info there.

511
00:28:52.160 --> 00:28:57.630
Really cool tool, DN map let's you
distribute those end map commands out or

512
00:28:57.630 --> 00:29:01.210
really call home and
retrieve those end map commands so

513
00:29:01.210 --> 00:29:04.160
that we don't have to write those
commands on every single machined.

514
00:29:04.160 --> 00:29:05.350
Fantastic.

515
00:29:05.350 --> 00:29:07.810
Anything else we want to toss
in before we wrap this one up?

516
00:29:09.495 --> 00:29:12.985
All I can is I hope that was
an interesting one to a lot of you,

517
00:29:12.985 --> 00:29:13.955
to a lot of people.

518
00:29:13.955 --> 00:29:18.905
I hope it's opening your eyes to something
else you can do that involves Nmap.

519
00:29:18.905 --> 00:29:23.395
Nmap's in so many things we've seen,
either directly or

520
00:29:23.395 --> 00:29:26.505
indirectly, this is just
another way of using that.

521
00:29:26.505 --> 00:29:31.470
Nmap reminds me kind of,
in a way reminds me of like turkey a bit.

522
00:29:31.470 --> 00:29:34.370
Because you go to like Subway or
something, there's turkey in that.

523
00:29:34.370 --> 00:29:35.070
It's not ham.

524
00:29:35.070 --> 00:29:35.690
It's turkey.

525
00:29:35.690 --> 00:29:38.350
It's like turkey of the IT world.

526
00:29:38.350 --> 00:29:42.270
It's just me.
>> [LAUGH] I think Sean's ready for lunch.

527
00:29:42.270 --> 00:29:43.680
>> Yeah.
>> All right ladies and

528
00:29:43.680 --> 00:29:46.000
gentlemen, we hope you
enjoyed watching this one.

529
00:29:46.000 --> 00:29:48.300
Signing off for ITProTV I'm Mike Roderick.

530
00:29:48.300 --> 00:29:49.120
>> And I'm Sean Oriyano.

531
00:29:49.120 --> 00:29:50.324
>> And we'll see you next time.

532
00:29:50.324 --> 00:29:56.020
