episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike look at the process of cracking passwords. They start by looking at ways to generate a list of targets. Then they use Crunch to generate a wordlist for password cracking. They also look at the password cracking utility Medusa, examining the options for launching a password cracking attack.
episodes.title: Password Cracking
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.119
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.119 --> 00:00:12.991
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode at ITProTV.

3
00:00:12.991 --> 00:00:14.900
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:14.900 --> 00:00:17.120
With me today is Mr. Sean Oriyano.

5
00:00:17.120 --> 00:00:21.610
And this episode, Sean, we're going to
be taking a look at password cracking.

6
00:00:21.610 --> 00:00:25.200
I know we've got a lot of viewers out
there that might want to see how something

7
00:00:25.200 --> 00:00:28.840
like this is done and Sean's gonna
walk us through the process of

8
00:00:28.840 --> 00:00:31.570
getting things ready to crack passwords.

9
00:00:31.570 --> 00:00:34.500
So Sean, where do we start?

10
00:00:34.500 --> 00:00:39.240
>> Well we've got a path
to kind of go down and

11
00:00:39.240 --> 00:00:42.930
to set up doing this whole
process of password cracking.

12
00:00:42.930 --> 00:00:47.500
It's something that yeah we've talked
about in other shows before and

13
00:00:47.500 --> 00:00:49.770
we've said that's possible to do it.

14
00:00:49.770 --> 00:00:54.670
So now what we're gonna do is we're
gonna talk about how it's done, and

15
00:00:54.670 --> 00:00:58.580
show you the process of getting
a ray to do the password crack,

16
00:00:58.580 --> 00:01:00.989
gathering targets, building a word list.

17
00:01:00.989 --> 00:01:05.150
And just getting to the point where
all you gotta do is hit Enter and

18
00:01:05.150 --> 00:01:06.980
let the thing rock and roll at that point.

19
00:01:06.980 --> 00:01:07.870
>> Thankfully for us,

20
00:01:07.870 --> 00:01:11.356
Sean is not gonna hit Enter so
my passwords are safe I think.

21
00:01:11.356 --> 00:01:15.249
[LAUGH] I hope, I'm going to be watching
his finger over that Enter button.

22
00:01:15.249 --> 00:01:16.057
>> It's like stop!

23
00:01:16.057 --> 00:01:18.774
[SOUND] Don't touch it.

24
00:01:18.774 --> 00:01:21.970
>> So I guess the first thing that we've
gotta do is we've gotta pick our targets.

25
00:01:21.970 --> 00:01:23.385
We've gotta figure out who
we're gonna attack and

26
00:01:23.385 --> 00:01:27.855
Sean you had a great way to build
a list pretty quickly and easily right?

27
00:01:27.855 --> 00:01:31.920
>> Yeah, you've got a list of options
as far as how to build to targets okay?

28
00:01:31.920 --> 00:01:35.450
So, the choice is really yours.

29
00:01:35.450 --> 00:01:38.910
But one of the easiest ways is
something that we've used time and

30
00:01:38.910 --> 00:01:42.120
time again which is to use Nmap.

31
00:01:42.120 --> 00:01:48.700
Nmap you can use it to do a quick
sweep of a subnet or you can use it to

32
00:01:48.700 --> 00:01:53.800
feed in a file to it and say here's some
subnets I want you to take a look at.

33
00:01:53.800 --> 00:01:54.430
Sweep it.

34
00:01:54.430 --> 00:01:59.500
Dump it out to a file and then you can
use that file as your target list.

35
00:01:59.500 --> 00:02:06.210
Easy way to that is you kind of want
to do it quickly, easily, and get

36
00:02:06.210 --> 00:02:12.870
that information dumped is I've brought
up a command line here on my screen.

37
00:02:12.870 --> 00:02:17.140
Which is just, I'm running Nmap,
I'm running Nmap and

38
00:02:17.140 --> 00:02:22.360
note the switch in there, it's -s,

39
00:02:22.360 --> 00:02:26.780
and then P, and
then I put in an IP subnet.

40
00:02:26.780 --> 00:02:29.440
And then put in my little
greater than symbol,

41
00:02:29.440 --> 00:02:32.210
and told it pipe it out to a text file.

42
00:02:32.210 --> 00:02:37.290
And all that's gonna do at that point,
once I go ahead and say, okay, that's my

43
00:02:37.290 --> 00:02:41.920
command I wanna run, hit Enter, it's gonna
go ahead and do what Nmap always does, and

44
00:02:41.920 --> 00:02:47.660
it does really well,
is to sweep that range of IP addresses.

45
00:02:47.660 --> 00:02:53.140
If you use something like a dat file,

46
00:02:53.140 --> 00:02:57.890
which is in this case, for nmap,
is just a simple text file,

47
00:02:57.890 --> 00:03:03.370
you can actually create a dat file
that has a list of subnets in it.

48
00:03:03.370 --> 00:03:06.560
And then just feed that right into
Nmap and it'll do the same thing.

49
00:03:06.560 --> 00:03:11.190
And what it'll do is it will
generate just a simple text file

50
00:03:11.190 --> 00:03:15.270
like we're doing here that has
a list of hosts inside of it.

51
00:03:15.270 --> 00:03:18.510
And you've seen that list before
get output to the screen.

52
00:03:18.510 --> 00:03:20.570
It's doing the same thing here.

53
00:03:20.570 --> 00:03:25.020
It's gonna take some time,
sweep that range of hosts, and

54
00:03:25.020 --> 00:03:27.520
then we'll have that host.txt.

55
00:03:27.520 --> 00:03:33.430
I'm scanning just in my
local VMware subnet in here,

56
00:03:33.430 --> 00:03:36.410
so it's nothing really
all that exciting and

57
00:03:36.410 --> 00:03:41.510
I think you get the idea what an IP Subnet
and range of IP addresses look like.

58
00:03:41.510 --> 00:03:45.380
But what I want you to note off
of this one is we're taking that,

59
00:03:45.380 --> 00:03:50.010
we're using Nmap to generate that
target list because it's much

60
00:03:50.010 --> 00:03:54.910
easier to do it this way than it would
be to just pipe them in individually.

61
00:03:54.910 --> 00:03:58.590
Now if you had an individual target you
wanted to do a password crack against,

62
00:03:58.590 --> 00:04:00.960
then you don't need to do this.

63
00:04:00.960 --> 00:04:04.150
You can take the NMap step,
push it aside and say, well,

64
00:04:04.150 --> 00:04:08.580
I'm not targeting the whole range of them,
here I am deciding that I do want to

65
00:04:08.580 --> 00:04:14.490
target a whole range of hosts for my
password attack so I'm building that list.

66
00:04:14.490 --> 00:04:18.680
Keep in mind though, do plan your stuff
out carefully here, very carefully

67
00:04:18.680 --> 00:04:23.810
because the implication here is when I do
Nmap and I'm building this list of hosts,

68
00:04:23.810 --> 00:04:28.930
let's say that suddenly it had 30,
40, 50 hosts on it.

69
00:04:28.930 --> 00:04:32.840
You're gonna run a password crack
against all of them doing it?

70
00:04:32.840 --> 00:04:37.120
Yeah, you better really think that
strategy through there because that's

71
00:04:37.120 --> 00:04:43.020

you could get caught relatively easily,

72
00:04:43.020 --> 00:04:46.170
especially if there is an IDS or
something running.

73
00:04:46.170 --> 00:04:50.350
So really think about if this
is the best strategy to do that.

74
00:04:50.350 --> 00:04:53.870
You might run NMAP just to
see which hosts are there and

75
00:04:53.870 --> 00:04:58.610
then maybe do a little extra stuff with
it to see what services are running and

76
00:04:58.610 --> 00:05:02.380
then use that for one of your later
phases we are going to talk about.

77
00:05:02.380 --> 00:05:05.960
But think about if it's just,
you wanna go just right across and

78
00:05:05.960 --> 00:05:07.230
say hey these hosts are up.

79
00:05:07.230 --> 00:05:10.520
I'm sweeping all these, I'm gonna sweep
all these hosts and target all of them.

80
00:05:10.520 --> 00:05:14.940
Probably not the best and
smartest idea to do, but you could do it.

81
00:05:14.940 --> 00:05:17.470
>> Not to mention extremely
time consuming, I would assume.

82
00:05:17.470 --> 00:05:21.120
>> Yeah, it could be very, very time
consuming to do that, especially if you're

83
00:05:21.120 --> 00:05:24.610
running a brute force attack or something,
that would be a very good point.

84
00:05:24.610 --> 00:05:28.130
A brute force attack against
one system can take a while.

85
00:05:28.130 --> 00:05:33.460
Against multiple systems, I mean, you're
really jacking that time up, you know,

86
00:05:33.460 --> 00:05:38.630
pretty high, so really think about this,
your strategy here, and plan it out.

87
00:05:38.630 --> 00:05:43.240
It sounds kinda cool and sexy from
a certain way to just, oh, well heck.

88
00:05:43.240 --> 00:05:46.490
Sweep a whole range of them and
password crack them all.

89
00:05:46.490 --> 00:05:48.420
You know, to hell with getting caught.

90
00:05:48.420 --> 00:05:50.590
It's not the goal here.

91
00:05:50.590 --> 00:05:56.010
So we wanna be very,
very careful about how we do things.

92
00:05:56.010 --> 00:05:59.490
When I put out that text file.

93
00:05:59.490 --> 00:06:03.000
I'm gonna get a text
file right out of NMAP.

94
00:06:03.000 --> 00:06:04.840
I've got this thing
highlighted right here.

95
00:06:04.840 --> 00:06:07.900
I'll just get a simple text file and
you can see that

96
00:06:07.900 --> 00:06:11.439
it actually finished obviously right when
as soon as I looked away [LAUGH] and

97
00:06:11.439 --> 00:06:12.887
not looking as it finishes.

98
00:06:12.887 --> 00:06:16.879
[LAUGH] I've got that text file here
with a list of IP addresses in it.

99
00:06:16.879 --> 00:06:21.863
You know, so,
once I've got that what I will

100
00:06:21.863 --> 00:06:26.977
do is take NMap out of
the picture the next thing

101
00:06:26.977 --> 00:06:31.890
to do is to move on to
creating a word list.

102
00:06:31.890 --> 00:06:32.440
Okay?

103
00:06:32.440 --> 00:06:33.790
Now this is your option.

104
00:06:33.790 --> 00:06:36.800
I'm going to use a brute
force attack here, but

00:06:36.800 --> 00:06:40.050
you don't have to use
a brute force attack.

106
00:06:40.050 --> 00:06:43.980
You can use other things as well, but

107
00:06:43.980 --> 00:06:46.450
we're just going to focus

108
00:06:46.450 --> 00:06:51.350
And so the way I would do, set up my
word list so I've got the host list.

109
00:06:51.350 --> 00:06:53.580
So I've got step where
I've got my target list.

110
00:06:53.580 --> 00:06:58.610
Next thing I've got is,
I want to do my actual word list.

111
00:06:58.610 --> 00:06:59.840
And the way to do that for

112
00:06:59.840 --> 00:07:06.240
brute forcing is I can do this actual
program on here called Crunch.

113
00:07:06.240 --> 00:07:10.590
Crunch is actually
a really easy tool to use.

114
00:07:10.590 --> 00:07:12.200
What you can do is do crunch.

115
00:07:12.200 --> 00:07:15.900
And what you're going to do is that
is going to tell you, you know,

116
00:07:15.900 --> 00:07:19.860
what the range in
passwords are going to be.

117
00:07:19.860 --> 00:07:24.280
Don't get cute with this, and
the reason why I'm saying and

118
00:07:24.280 --> 00:07:28.630
mean by that is, when you go through and
type into this minute max, don't say oh,

119
00:07:28.630 --> 00:07:33.250
well I want to have everything

120
00:07:33.250 --> 00:07:35.650
You type that in and
hit Enter, guess what?

121
00:07:35.650 --> 00:07:37.100
It's going to take awhile.

122
00:07:37.100 --> 00:07:42.290
You better go and raise your kids
from the age of three to five,

00:07:42.290 --> 00:07:45.170

124
00:07:45.170 --> 00:07:49.065
>> Something we would probably want to
do ahead of time if we do need to use

125
00:07:49.065 --> 00:07:50.623
password links that long.

126
00:07:50.623 --> 00:07:54.329
Also I would think this is where our

127
00:07:54.329 --> 00:07:57.620
if we go back to the hacking lifecycle or

128
00:07:57.620 --> 00:08:02.200
Maybe having an idea of what their
password policy is, so that I know what

129
00:08:02.200 --> 00:08:06.870

is enabled, and things like that.

130
00:08:06.870 --> 00:08:08.220
That might help in this phase.

131
00:08:08.220 --> 00:08:11.680
>> Yeah, Mike's got an interesting point,
got a very interesting,

132
00:08:11.680 --> 00:08:15.270
excellent point there,

are cracking if you're following the

134
00:08:19.840 --> 00:08:23.595
One of those is to do a scanning.

00:08:23.595 --> 00:08:28.862
Part of its enumeration, you're trying
to extract what services are running and

136
00:08:28.862 --> 00:08:31.393
on top of that, enumerations is okay.

137
00:08:31.393 --> 00:08:36.869
Let's pull banners out of it and we could
see maybe, for some of those banners,

138
00:08:36.869 --> 00:08:41.283
they might be able to tell us what
the password policy there is and

139
00:08:41.283 --> 00:08:44.010
that may not be too difficult to grasp.

140
00:08:44.010 --> 00:08:47.240
But if somebody is doing
what we saw in our

141
00:08:48.815 --> 00:08:54.095
a little bit of in the episode
we did on Responder.

142
00:08:54.095 --> 00:08:56.945
Net BIOS is running in a lot of places.

143
00:08:56.945 --> 00:09:01.615
Net bias may be your
point of entry to go in,

144
00:09:01.615 --> 00:09:06.220
and pull those policy settings off of it,
and say I can narrow it down a bit more.

145

My passwords are so

What we did here is we actually

we went across multiple steps.

We even talked about some things

For example,

you were talking about how to find out

We did our password cracking with Medusa,

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike take a look at OpenVAS. They compare OpenVAS with other vulnerability scanners. Then they go through the initial configuration, run a scan, and look at the results.
episodes.title: Scanning with OpenVAS

1

[MUSIC]

I'm not gonna use it, actually is

If you wanna use an SS after this,

There is any one number of ones that got a

I want you to know that not only does
Kali 2.0 put this right in there, and

the updates and stuff like that process,

I really really like that.

What's not to love about it?

You've got it at your fingertips time to

Mike just reiterated it to

So if you're using Nessus and

That's what they're meant for.

But you cannot use this

If you're caught doing that,

And you're kind of stuck because they

So do remember that there, those ones,

Whatever, I can understand it, you still

But do remember, you got a choice,

You can stay compliant with licensing, or

use it for your commercial stuff and

442
00:25:44.760 --> 00:25:49.490
have with a few exceptions here and
there you could still be

443
00:25:49.490 --> 00:25:54.340
well within the range of the power

444
00:25:54.340 --> 00:25:55.250
>> Very good.

Exactly, licensing you

446
00:25:59.260 --> 00:26:03.970
>> The thing I would add to that
is it's very easy to violate that

00:26:03.970 --> 00:26:05.860
type of things, you know.

00:26:05.860 --> 00:26:09.150
I've had it when, I didn't even think

00:26:09.150 --> 00:26:13.120
teaching classes and stuff like that, I'll
just grab some piece of virtualization

00:26:13.120 --> 00:26:15.030
software, you know, for example.

And I'm just like using it, it's like,
oh wait a minute, that's saying,

Because it's no longer me just sitting

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike look at two web vulnerability scanners, Skipfish and Vega. They start with Vega, scanning a couple of websites and analyzing the results. Next they contrast that with Skipfish, a command line utility.
episodes.title: Scanning with Skipfish and Vega
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.170
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.170 --> 00:00:14.871
Hello, and welcome to another episode of
ITProTV, I'm your host, Mike Rodrick, and

3
00:00:14.871 --> 00:00:16.800
with me today is Mr. Sean Oriyano.

4
00:00:16.800 --> 00:00:20.590
And Sean, in this episode, we're gonna be
taking a look at vulnerability scanners.

5
00:00:20.590 --> 00:00:24.788
And in particular, we're gonna be looking
at a couple of web vulnerability scanners

00:00:24.788 --> 00:00:26.372

7
00:00:26.372 --> 00:00:27.210
Right?

8

>> Yes, that's the goal here.

Is that we are taking a look at

00:00:32.700 --> 00:00:33.860

I chose Skipfish and

Vega because they are ones that

13
00:00:39.650 --> 00:00:45.090
And they kind of enhance the existing

00:00:45.090 --> 00:00:50.010
So what we want to do is see why use

15
00:00:50.010 --> 00:00:54.010
And so these two,
one of them is a command line.

00:00:54.010 --> 00:00:58.091
The other one is gonna be using a GUI.

17

So it's just kind of to show you,
and compare and contrast the two.

Okay, so, they're both really neat.

They're very simple.

They both have their pros and cons, so

You can still do other application

00:01:18.337 --> 00:01:21.700
your Expose, the stuff we
mentioned in the previous episode,

24
00:01:21.700 --> 00:01:24.340
with OpenVAS you have that available too.

25
00:01:24.340 --> 00:01:27.430
So you've still got quite
a few things open to you.

26
00:01:27.430 --> 00:01:31.230
This is just gonna enhance
your existing capability.

27
00:01:31.230 --> 00:01:34.250
So I think you'll like these things, and

28
00:01:34.250 --> 00:01:38.750
you'll find them to be something that is a
good enhancement to what you already have.

29
00:01:38.750 --> 00:01:42.690
So what we'll do is,
to kinda get the ball rolling here,

30
00:01:42.690 --> 00:01:48.610
the first one we will take a look

31
00:01:48.610 --> 00:01:51.835
Vega, I've already kind of
started it up for us and

00:01:51.835 --> 00:01:55.146
I'm letting it kind of do

33
00:01:55.146 --> 00:02:00.773
I've got my own website scan here.

34
00:02:00.773 --> 00:02:07.725
And so it's gone through and I have

35
00:02:07.725 --> 00:02:08.905
So it's found some stuff.

36
00:02:08.905 --> 00:02:12.485
I also ran a quick, kinda just sweep

37
00:02:12.485 --> 00:02:19.590

38
00:02:19.590 --> 00:02:24.430
And so, this stuff, like I said,
this stuff is doing kind of what a search

00:02:24.430 --> 00:02:27.460
would do, but it's putting a little
more attention on telling you,

40
00:02:27.460 --> 00:02:31.760
hey, types of issues added that it

41
00:02:31.760 --> 00:02:34.520
>> So like most of our vulnerability
scanners, it's got a database,

42
00:02:34.520 --> 00:02:38.050
I'm assuming, of the vulnerabilities and
it's kinda comparing results against that.

43
00:02:38.050 --> 00:02:38.804
>> Yeah exactly.

44
00:02:38.804 --> 00:02:39.710
>> NIce.

45
00:02:39.710 --> 00:02:43.810
>> So it can build a pretty
substantial piece of information,

46
00:02:43.810 --> 00:02:45.560
a picture on what it finds.

47
00:02:45.560 --> 00:02:48.380
So I find this to be
a very very handy tool.

48
00:02:48.380 --> 00:02:51.650
If you're a web application developer,
or if you've just got a regular website,

49
00:02:51.650 --> 00:02:55.930
whatever, it can help you find a lot
of those things that may not be as

50
00:02:55.930 --> 00:02:59.450
obvious to you and
stuff that you want to take care of.

51
00:02:59.450 --> 00:03:06.265
So the two websites that I have, I've got

52
00:03:06.265 --> 00:03:08.565
It's completed, since it's a small site.

53
00:03:08.565 --> 00:03:15.605
And it's given me an overall report on it,
saying, hey, I found some issues here.

54
00:03:15.605 --> 00:03:19.625
So when I go over here is,
I can just click on that scan, and

00:03:19.625 --> 00:03:23.400
it says here's a medium issue and
it says well found an issue, though,

56
00:03:23.400 --> 00:03:26.140
I think something found

57
00:03:26.140 --> 00:03:30.600
Well, I can look at and see if that's
really an issue, and kinda review it, and

58
00:03:30.600 --> 00:03:32.360
then go look at the source code.

59
00:03:32.360 --> 00:03:37.270
It's gonna tell me what page and
location it found that in, if possible.

60
00:03:37.270 --> 00:03:40.900
So, it's finding one here it thinks
it's actually might be a concern.

61
00:03:40.900 --> 00:03:43.659
So I can take a look at that to see
if that's something that needs to

62
00:03:43.659 --> 00:03:44.660

63
00:03:44.660 --> 00:03:45.630
And that's good.

64
00:03:45.630 --> 00:03:47.370
It could be something that you've missed.

65
00:03:47.370 --> 00:03:53.160
It could be something that's completely

66
00:03:53.160 --> 00:03:56.755

got information right here telling me,

67
00:03:56.755 --> 00:04:01.245
hey this is what I found, and I can decide
what type of action I want to take.

68
00:04:01.245 --> 00:04:05.665
>> Yeah a lot better than, at least you
found it and you can make the decision

69
00:04:05.665 --> 00:04:08.880
rather than the bad guy finding it and
taking advantage of it for you.

70
00:04:08.880 --> 00:04:09.545
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah,

71
00:04:09.545 --> 00:04:12.705
you don't want the bad guys
eating your lunch on this at all.

72
00:04:12.705 --> 00:04:18.970
So right now you've got a really
good idea looking at this.

73
00:04:18.970 --> 00:04:22.010
And this would be just one that
you'd just have in your arsenal,

74
00:04:22.010 --> 00:04:25.870
you do have other vulnerability scanners
as well that you would want to use, and

75
00:04:25.870 --> 00:04:29.310
see if they are actually, you know,
gonna give you different information.

76
00:04:29.310 --> 00:04:32.140
And remember, they will give you
different information sometimes.

77
00:04:32.140 --> 00:04:36.270
Just because one gives you what looks like
a complete picture, doesn't mean that

78
00:04:36.270 --> 00:04:43.020
your, oh great I could just kind of
clean my hands and say I'm done with it.

79
00:04:43.020 --> 00:04:45.260
Run another one, it may actually
give you a different viewpoint, and

80
00:04:45.260 --> 00:04:47.330
say well wait a minute,
how come that one didn't say it?

81
00:04:47.330 --> 00:04:51.490
Well that one didn't say it because maybe
that was overlooked by the developer.

82
00:04:51.490 --> 00:04:53.340
The same reason you're
using something like this,

83
00:04:53.340 --> 00:04:55.380
the developer could have
missed something too.

84
00:04:55.380 --> 00:04:58.570
In which case you've caught it now.

85
00:04:58.570 --> 00:05:02.760
>> It's a lot like the old spyware we used
to use where they rely on a database.

86
00:05:02.760 --> 00:05:06.920
And I'm sure the different vulnerability
scanners don't use the same database.

87
00:05:06.920 --> 00:05:10.990
So if somebody's added a new entry to
one database one company has, the other

88
00:05:10.990 --> 00:05:14.410
company might be behind in adding new
definitions or new vulnerabilities.

89
00:05:14.410 --> 00:05:18.399
So, definitely important to run more than
one to make sure you get the full picture.

90
00:05:18.399 --> 00:05:21.443
>> Yeah,
you make a really good point on that is,

91
00:05:21.443 --> 00:05:25.760
that the databases don't
necessarily have to be the same.

92
00:05:25.760 --> 00:05:28.710
They do pull information from
a lot of common sources, but

93
00:05:28.710 --> 00:05:31.550
they also do put their own things into it.

94
00:05:31.550 --> 00:05:36.132
So, you'll see some of these vulnerability
databases that you could search yourself

95
00:05:36.132 --> 00:05:37.500
on your own.

96
00:05:37.500 --> 00:05:39.730
They will sometimes,
you go out there and pull the stuff,

97
00:05:39.730 --> 00:05:43.770
those databases, and
stick them into their product.

98
00:05:43.770 --> 00:05:47.680
And by scanning through multiple databases
they can get you a clearer picture.

99
00:05:47.680 --> 00:05:52.150
But they can also have these other
things that they've built on their own.

100
00:05:52.150 --> 00:05:56.360
And which case, that knowledge base isn't
the same between different vendors.

101
00:05:56.360 --> 00:05:59.310
So you're going to want to make
sure that you try different ones.

102
00:05:59.310 --> 00:06:01.419
So there could be some commonalities.

103
00:06:01.419 --> 00:06:03.375
But not 100%.

104
00:06:03.375 --> 00:06:06.640
Don't expect that.
It's always good to do that sanity check

105
00:06:06.640 --> 00:06:09.710
and as we always say here,
trust but verify.

106
00:06:09.710 --> 00:06:16.102
Make sure that you're actually getting
that clear picture that you want.

107
00:06:16.102 --> 00:06:18.083
>> Very good.
>> So I look at this here,

108
00:06:18.083 --> 00:06:23.190
I've got a view,
I've got my website mapped out here.

109
00:06:23.190 --> 00:06:26.380
And like I said, it's giving me
that picture of things down here.

110
00:06:26.380 --> 00:06:28.160
Here I even have an info one.

00:06:28.160 --> 00:06:31.140
I can take a look at that to see,
well it says there's something,

112
00:06:31.140 --> 00:06:33.600
it thinks there's a newsfeed there.

113
00:06:33.600 --> 00:06:38.100
I could take a look to see if this is
a problem, and it's saying alrighty this

114
00:06:38.100 --> 00:06:41.620
isn't probably a problem anyway
because it says it's an RSS feed or

115
00:06:41.620 --> 00:06:43.890
did you mean to have this here or not?

116
00:06:43.890 --> 00:06:47.450
So you could decide if that's
something that's of interest to you.

117
00:06:47.450 --> 00:06:54.560
But that's just a look at one
website being scanned with this.

118
00:06:54.560 --> 00:06:59.020
I have scanned something
a little more complicated, or

119
00:06:59.020 --> 00:07:02.820
a lot more complicated,
which is actually still going on.

120
00:07:02.820 --> 00:07:07.276
This one, just FYI, I've actually
manipulated these results a bit, too, so

121
00:07:07.276 --> 00:07:10.549
don't go looking, oh,
USA Today's got all this stuff.

122
00:07:10.549 --> 00:07:12.620
No, no, no.
I played with it a bit to make it

123
00:07:12.620 --> 00:07:14.540
a little more interesting for

124
00:07:14.540 --> 00:07:17.920
us to show you just the kind of breadth
of things that could be in there.

125
00:07:17.920 --> 00:07:23.040
Anyway, so what I have,
as you can see in this one,

126
00:07:23.040 --> 00:07:26.510
with the results that I've gotten
from here and like I said,

127
00:07:26.510 --> 00:07:31.970
I've kinda tweaked them a bit to make it
more interesting, to show more stuff.

128
00:07:31.970 --> 00:07:36.812
You take a look at this one,
it says it found 202 high errors in here,

129
00:07:36.812 --> 00:07:39.086
so that's a little concerning.

130
00:07:39.086 --> 00:07:43.084
You know. [LAUGH] >> That's when I go to
my damn team and say, are you working?

131
00:07:43.084 --> 00:07:46.400
[LAUGH]
>> All vacations are cancelled as of now.

132
00:07:46.400 --> 00:07:49.192
>> [LAUGH]
>> So I look at this and

133
00:07:49.192 --> 00:07:53.304
I could start doing the same thing,
picking through it.

134
00:07:53.304 --> 00:07:57.576
And you can see it's really it's
flagging these things, telling you hey,

135
00:07:57.576 --> 00:08:01.511
this is This is what I found as being
a problem, and it gives you the full

00:08:01.511 --> 00:08:05.912
description in it, and it even, like I
said, it weights them, it tells you,

137
00:08:05.912 --> 00:08:10.515
this is a pretty serious one, this is

00:21:39.200 --> 00:21:42.132
But the point of the matter
is you have that report.

359
00:21:42.132 --> 00:21:45.295
If someone wants a report
that they can click through,

360
00:21:45.295 --> 00:21:49.696
it's a report that they can click through,
really quickly and easily, but

361
00:21:49.696 --> 00:21:54.110
it gives you the same type of information
albeit in a different format.

362
00:21:54.110 --> 00:21:58.938
It gives you the same type of
information something like Vega would or

363
00:21:58.938 --> 00:22:02.611
any of the other web
vulnerability scanners would.

364
00:22:02.611 --> 00:22:08.236
I just happen to find I like Skipfish,
because it's so simplistic.

365
00:22:08.236 --> 00:22:14.823
I mean, all you need to do is just
let the thing just go ahead and

366
00:22:14.823 --> 00:22:20.220
run and I'm just [SOUND] go ahead and
do whatever.

367
00:22:20.220 --> 00:22:24.351
I could actually open up another Skipfish
session against something else and

368
00:22:24.351 --> 00:22:26.163
let that go ahead and run.

369
00:22:26.163 --> 00:22:28.820
>> Command line,
it's scriptable, I'm sure.

370
00:22:28.820 --> 00:22:30.932
>> Yeah, you could script it, absolutely.

371
00:22:30.932 --> 00:22:35.255
So that's such a just neat thing to
be able to have and since it's so

372
00:22:35.255 --> 00:22:40.140
lightweight, anything that's got that
GUI is gonna have more overhead.

373
00:22:40.140 --> 00:22:44.077
This one's so lightweight and
can do its job very quickly.

374
00:22:44.077 --> 00:22:48.590
And the guy, actually that does this
updates the database all the time.

375
00:22:48.590 --> 00:22:51.225
So, it's a command line tool
that he updates the database and

376
00:22:51.225 --> 00:22:52.702
he actually has an email address.

377
00:22:52.702 --> 00:22:55.437
You can contact him,
if you have problems with it and or

378
00:22:55.437 --> 00:22:58.040
it's not picking up something or whatever.

379
00:22:58.040 --> 00:23:02.789
And he'll respond back to you and you,
oh, well, let me incorporate that or

380
00:23:02.789 --> 00:23:05.286
let me tweak this or have you tried this?

381
00:23:05.286 --> 00:23:07.430
So he's right.

382
00:23:07.430 --> 00:23:09.095
The developer, this is right there.

383
00:23:09.095 --> 00:23:09.797
>> Fantastic.

384
00:23:09.797 --> 00:23:11.939
>> Yeah, so really, really great tool.

385
00:23:11.939 --> 00:23:15.901
So that just kind of,
these aren't the only two, but

386
00:23:15.901 --> 00:23:19.952
we're showing you Vega,
all the GUI side of things and

387
00:23:19.952 --> 00:23:26.070
then Skipfish using a command line, so
you can choose which way you want to go.

388
00:23:26.070 --> 00:23:29.740
They both will get you there, it's just
a question of which one's your preference?

389
00:23:29.740 --> 00:23:30.960
>> Very good, Sean.

390
00:23:30.960 --> 00:23:35.450
Well, a lot of great information on
a couple of the web vulnerability scanners

391
00:23:35.450 --> 00:23:40.429
that we've got available in our arsenal
under Kali 2.0, we got Skipfish and Vega.

392
00:23:40.429 --> 00:23:43.820
But looking at the clock, it's about
time for us to wrap this one up.

393
00:23:43.820 --> 00:23:46.210
Any parting thoughts for us, Sean?

394
00:23:46.210 --> 00:23:50.092
>> Not really, I think you got a good
look at the reports and the way this

395
00:23:50.092 --> 00:23:54.270
things work and it's up to you to go
through and try it out now, I guess.

396
00:23:54.270 --> 00:23:57.657
>> Get out there and play and
remember, when you have permission.

397
00:23:57.657 --> 00:24:01.302
Well, ladies and gentlemen, we hope you
enjoyed watching this one signing off for

398
00:24:01.302 --> 00:24:02.670
ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

399
00:24:02.670 --> 00:24:03.779
>> And I'm Sean Oriyano.

400
00:24:03.779 --> 00:24:04.931
>> And we'll see you next time.

401
00:24:04.931 --> 00:24:11.220
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Don look at Zed Attack Proxy, a web application vulnerability scanner. They use ZAP to scan a website and analyze the results. They look at the features in ZAP, and the different modules available to extend the functionality of ZAP.
episodes.title: Working with Zed Proxy
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.240
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.240 --> 00:00:12.757
All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening.

3
00:00:12.757 --> 00:00:15.047
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.047 --> 00:00:18.861
I'm your host Don Pezet,
back again with Mr. Sean Oriyano.

5
00:00:18.861 --> 00:00:22.350
We're diving right back into
the world of Kali Linux 2.0.

6
00:00:22.350 --> 00:00:25.800
And, well, in particular, we've got
the Zed Proxy lined up for today.

7
00:00:25.800 --> 00:00:26.400
Right, Sean?

8
00:00:26.400 --> 00:00:28.083
>> Yup, that's what we've got.

9
00:00:28.083 --> 00:00:33.560
I love the name of it, Zed Attack Proxy,
or they sometimes call it ZAP.

10
00:00:33.560 --> 00:00:37.917
But, you know, what it is,
it's actually a web vulnerability scanner,

11
00:00:37.917 --> 00:00:40.840
or a web application scanner specifically.

12
00:00:40.840 --> 00:00:45.940
But we can use it to point at websites and
it'll crawl the websites

13
00:00:45.940 --> 00:00:50.680
to see if it finds vulnerabilities for us
and give us information on what it finds.

14
00:00:50.680 --> 00:00:58.420
And it gives us time to kind of put our
skills to use or to call our developer or

15
00:00:58.420 --> 00:01:03.130
decide what the best course of action
is based on the problems that it finds.

16
00:01:03.130 --> 00:01:08.050
So it's a pretty nice tool to have
considering that web applications,

17
00:01:08.050 --> 00:01:11.990
they can be some of the toughest things
and most complex things you may run into.

18
00:01:11.990 --> 00:01:14.950
>> But we're really fortunate because
most web developers out there,

19
00:01:14.950 --> 00:01:16.541
they think security first, right?

20
00:01:16.541 --> 00:01:17.888
I mean security's baked into
everything they develop.

21
00:01:17.888 --> 00:01:20.926
>> Oh absolutely.

22
00:01:20.926 --> 00:01:25.408
>> [LAUGH] SImple things like field
validation, or even limiting,

23
00:01:25.408 --> 00:01:29.690
all sorts of, the SQL injection attacks
you hear, they almost all tie back to

24
00:01:29.690 --> 00:01:32.600
these web application vulnerabilities so
it is really big problem right?

25
00:01:32.600 --> 00:01:36.610
>> Yeah absolutely,
it can turn into a huge problem for you.

26
00:01:36.610 --> 00:01:39.930
This is something that we've seen for
years,

27
00:01:39.930 --> 00:01:43.440
we still see going on,
there's just been so many of them.

28
00:01:43.440 --> 00:01:47.679
We've had vulnerabilities and
attacks recently against what,

29
00:01:47.679 --> 00:01:50.186
Office of Personnel Management had one.

30
00:01:50.186 --> 00:01:54.460
In fact I had read one just a few days
ago that they were talking about over

31
00:01:54.460 --> 00:01:57.620
a four year period that,
did you see the one in USA Today?

32
00:01:57.620 --> 00:01:59.830
>> Yeah it was like Department of
Transportation or somebody like that.

33
00:01:59.830 --> 00:02:00.620
>> Department of Energy, yeah.

34
00:02:00.620 --> 00:02:01.360
>> Oh, Department of Energy.

35
00:02:01.360 --> 00:02:01.987
Yeah, that was it.

36
00:02:01.987 --> 00:02:06.470
>> About 1,200 attacks over a 4 year
period, 160 of them are successful.

37
00:02:06.470 --> 00:02:08.280
So, well that's good, right?

38
00:02:08.280 --> 00:02:10.905
Statistically, it's not that high.

39
00:02:10.905 --> 00:02:11.820
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

40
00:02:11.820 --> 00:02:14.821
the list just keeps going on and on.

41
00:02:14.821 --> 00:02:17.610
I mean, you wanna reach back,
there's people like Target and Sony and

42
00:02:17.610 --> 00:02:18.750
keep going on and on and on.

43
00:02:18.750 --> 00:02:22.770
So obviously, this is a prime target.

44
00:02:22.770 --> 00:02:28.970
You consider the fact that a web server
and web application, for the attackers,

45
00:02:28.970 --> 00:02:33.090
is probably one of the first places that
they're gonna make contact with you.

46
00:02:33.090 --> 00:02:37.420
It's gonna be the place that's gonna serve
as a good entry point to go further in.

47
00:02:37.420 --> 00:02:41.600
To either pull information off the site,
to bust in through

48
00:02:41.600 --> 00:02:46.120
things like SQL injections down the road,
cross site scripting could be a problem.

49
00:02:46.120 --> 00:02:47.700
There's a number of exploits,

50
00:02:47.700 --> 00:02:52.760
so having tools like
the Zed Attack Proxy is very handy.

51
00:02:52.760 --> 00:03:00.560
Now, just to kind of put it in context,
there is another tool that we've seen

52
00:03:00.560 --> 00:03:06.010
in the past that kinda sorta fits in
the same category as Zed Attack Proxy.

53
00:03:06.010 --> 00:03:08.130
It's something called Burp Suite.

54
00:03:08.130 --> 00:03:12.270
What Burp Suite does is something that
acts as a proxy between your actual

55
00:03:12.270 --> 00:03:16.000
browser and
whatever resource you're trying to access.

56
00:03:16.000 --> 00:03:20.560
So it filters all your requests back and
forth through Burp Suite and

57
00:03:20.560 --> 00:03:26.006
it can actually intercept those requests
and tell you hey, this is what I found.

58
00:03:26.006 --> 00:03:29.295
And you could choose to alter that
request or send it out unaltered or

59
00:03:29.295 --> 00:03:30.852
drop it to see how things react,

60
00:03:30.852 --> 00:03:34.620
which is kinda cool to be able to see
those headers as they move back and forth.

61
00:03:34.620 --> 00:03:39.850
As an application developer,
tremendous value there.

62
00:03:39.850 --> 00:03:43.500
Now, the cool thing about is that
it's not the only one that does it.

63
00:03:43.500 --> 00:03:47.050
And one of the benefits of the Burp Suite,
however,

64
00:03:47.050 --> 00:03:50.028
is that it runs pretty much cross
platform, because it's written in Java.

65
00:03:50.028 --> 00:03:54.955
The Zed Attack Proxy, you can get it for
Windows, and you can get it for Linux.

66
00:03:54.955 --> 00:03:58.935
Obviously it's running Kali,
we're running it in Linux.

67
00:03:58.935 --> 00:04:04.015
So we're gonna use it to kind
of take a look at a site or two.

68
00:04:04.015 --> 00:04:06.065
Anything that I'm doing here that doesn't,

69
00:04:06.065 --> 00:04:08.115
that were not actually
penetrating into a site.

70
00:04:08.115 --> 00:04:10.765
Just keep that in mind, it looks like it.

71
00:04:10.765 --> 00:04:11.949
As far as you guys know,

72
00:04:11.949 --> 00:04:14.923
I'm not penetrating anyone's
site without permission.

73
00:04:14.923 --> 00:04:15.747
They'll pick it up in a second.

74
00:04:15.747 --> 00:04:18.437
>> As far as you guys know, I like that.

75
00:04:18.437 --> 00:04:19.020
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

76
00:04:19.020 --> 00:04:21.082
>> This is not really happening, trust us.

77
00:04:21.082 --> 00:04:24.150
>> [LAUGH] If you're watching,
this is a recording.

78
00:04:24.150 --> 00:04:27.885
We edited out that part
where I have permission.

79
00:04:27.885 --> 00:04:29.880
[LAUGH] We'll edit it in post.

80
00:04:29.880 --> 00:04:33.620
But in any case,
what I have up here onscreen is,

81
00:04:33.620 --> 00:04:36.550
I do have this Zed Attack Proxy.

82
00:04:36.550 --> 00:04:40.460
Notice that it's got
the acronym OWASP up there.

83
00:04:40.460 --> 00:04:42.600
Wait, what did you say it was?

84
00:04:42.600 --> 00:04:44.030
>> Actually,
I just looked this one up Sean, so

85
00:04:44.030 --> 00:04:49.410
I can cheat a little bit, it's the Open
Web Application Security Project, OWASP.

86
00:04:49.410 --> 00:04:55.060
>> They have other tools and
other guides that they put out.

87
00:04:55.060 --> 00:04:59.210
One of the ones that I think about
is something called a Paros proxy.

88
00:04:59.210 --> 00:05:02.910
Paros proxy has actually been around for
ages.

89
00:05:02.910 --> 00:05:04.420
It's been phased out.

90
00:05:04.420 --> 00:05:06.760
You will still see that mentioned in some

91
00:05:09.860 --> 00:05:14.450
circles where you can to do web
application checks and all that.

92
00:05:14.450 --> 00:05:18.710
It's something if you wanna
use you could use but

93
00:05:18.710 --> 00:05:22.150
I advise against it because they
basically replaced that with this.

94
00:05:22.150 --> 00:05:27.180
And so just so you know the kind of
the relationship between those ones is

95
00:05:27.180 --> 00:05:32.820
Paros proxy has kinda metamorphosized and
evolved and became the Zed Attack Proxy.

96
00:05:32.820 --> 00:05:34.085
It grew up and got a cooler name.

97
00:05:34.085 --> 00:05:38.271
[LAUGH]
>> Sean for my own benefit,

98
00:05:38.271 --> 00:05:41.720
I always have a hard time with the Kali
menus cuz there's so many tools.

99
00:05:41.720 --> 00:05:43.500
Which menu is this one nested under?

100
00:05:43.500 --> 00:05:45.050
>> Oh great question.

101
00:05:45.050 --> 00:05:48.770
This is the thing,
if you're going through this,

102
00:05:48.770 --> 00:05:53.890
this is what I really like about Kali in
here is that this one is right under,

103
00:05:53.890 --> 00:05:56.560
this version of Kali,
Web Application Analysis.

104
00:05:56.560 --> 00:06:00.610
You wanna do web applications scan,
it's right in Web Application Analysis.

105
00:06:00.610 --> 00:06:03.720
You can see OWASP and ZAP right there.

106
00:06:03.720 --> 00:06:07.350
So they've really organized
it pretty well in here.

107
00:06:07.350 --> 00:06:12.098
It's one of those things in intro where
we were talking about the difference in

108
00:06:12.098 --> 00:06:16.270
the interface,
this is a prime example of it.

109
00:06:16.270 --> 00:06:19.570
Right here is how useful this would be.

110
00:06:19.570 --> 00:06:23.090
Don brings up the question
saying yeah to show just exactly

111
00:06:23.090 --> 00:06:27.060
where this is on the menu,
but you could also,

112
00:06:27.060 --> 00:06:31.110
if that question hadn't been asked,
it's a great question, but

113
00:06:31.110 --> 00:06:35.160
if the question hadn't been asked and
instead of what's that tool again?

114
00:06:35.160 --> 00:06:38.810
He's looking at a website,
you probably could open it up and

115
00:06:38.810 --> 00:06:40.380
find it in a few clicks anyway.

116
00:06:40.380 --> 00:06:41.530
So that's a big plus, so

117
00:06:41.530 --> 00:06:46.580
that just shows right there just
how easy it is to find things.

118
00:06:46.580 --> 00:06:52.060
But, keep in mind, something I
was saying in the intro as well,

119
00:06:52.060 --> 00:06:57.240
not every tool that is in Kali is
gonna be on one of these menus.

120
00:06:57.240 --> 00:06:58.950
So, that's the other thing.

121
00:06:58.950 --> 00:07:02.945
Notice it does say Favorites up top, it's
basically, by implication, telling you

122
00:07:02.945 --> 00:07:07.007
they're not all there, these are just the
ones they think you're gonna use the most.

123
00:07:07.007 --> 00:07:10.025
So, great thing to remember.

124
00:07:10.025 --> 00:07:13.183
So it starts.

125
00:07:13.183 --> 00:07:14.650
Let's go ahead and start up.

126
00:07:14.650 --> 00:07:17.860
When you start this up the first time,
I already started up for us so we're not

127
00:07:17.860 --> 00:07:20.880
sitting here, kind of just like, hey,
what are you guys doing for dinner later?

128
00:07:20.880 --> 00:07:24.245
I went ahead and started it up for you.

129
00:07:24.245 --> 00:07:25.835
So you can,

130
00:07:25.835 --> 00:07:29.975
when you start it up the first time, it
may very well ask you to do updates to it.

131
00:07:29.975 --> 00:07:31.485
That's possible.

132
00:07:31.485 --> 00:07:35.105
That's one of the things that we
talked about in a previous episode,

133
00:07:35.105 --> 00:07:40.810
is if you know you're gonna be using
certain tools as part of your toolkit,

134
00:07:40.810 --> 00:07:44.030
then you probably want to go ahead and
get used to starting these

135
00:07:44.030 --> 00:07:47.810
things when you first load Kali to
get used to getting them updates and

136
00:07:47.810 --> 00:07:50.160
get the latest versions and
everything in there, okay?

137
00:07:50.160 --> 00:07:53.365
So I've already done that for
us, we're ready to go.

138
00:07:53.365 --> 00:07:57.404
So the quick way to kinda go through and

139
00:07:57.404 --> 00:08:03.853
look at the way the ZAP Proxy
works Is gonna ask URL to attack.

140
00:08:03.853 --> 00:08:05.860
So you're gonna pop that right in there.

141
00:08:06.860 --> 00:08:11.200
Now the way you do it is,
I've typed in my own website.

142
00:08:11.200 --> 00:08:12.990
And my own website,

143
00:08:12.990 --> 00:08:17.530
there's nothing really all that
interesting as far as web applications go.

144
00:08:17.530 --> 00:08:20.030
As far as me it's got lots
of interesting stuff.

145
00:08:20.030 --> 00:08:21.190
It's got pictures of me doing

146
00:08:21.190 --> 00:08:22.490
stuff like this and-
>> [LAUGH]

147
00:08:22.490 --> 00:08:23.390
>> And hanging out

148
00:08:23.390 --> 00:08:24.410
with the President, stuff like that.

149
00:08:24.410 --> 00:08:26.310
There's a lot of people looking right now.

150
00:08:26.310 --> 00:08:30.500
But anyway, so
once you type in the URL you wanna do,

151
00:08:30.500 --> 00:08:36.920
you just click Attack and it's gonna
go ahead and start doing its deal.

152
00:08:36.920 --> 00:08:40.950
And what you see there at the bottom is
you see that it's actually taking steps.

153
00:08:40.950 --> 00:08:44.080
It's running through and
sweeping that site for me and

154
00:08:44.080 --> 00:08:48.320
seeing, could it find it,
size of the site response time.

155
00:08:48.320 --> 00:08:53.050
It's giving me all that information so
right on through.

156
00:08:53.050 --> 00:08:55.050
>> Is this invasive?

157
00:08:55.050 --> 00:08:57.020
This isn't like just a passive scan.

158
00:08:57.020 --> 00:09:02.130
This is actively going in and
trying to perform some of these exploits?

159
00:09:02.130 --> 00:09:04.170
>> It's looking to see what
it can find at this level.

160
00:09:04.170 --> 00:09:05.950
It's looking to see what
it can find on the surface.

161
00:09:05.950 --> 00:09:10.510
This wouldn't be really any different
than, that far removed from having

162
00:09:10.510 --> 00:09:16.230
something like a Google going through
their spiders and looking at a site.

163
00:09:16.230 --> 00:09:18.080
It's not that far removed from it.

164
00:09:18.080 --> 00:09:20.490
Except this has an emphasis on looking for

165
00:09:20.490 --> 00:09:25.150
certain problems that it can fingerprint,
and say, I know what that is.

166
00:09:25.150 --> 00:09:27.090
>> Okay.
So it hasn't actually used them,

167
00:09:27.090 --> 00:09:31.290
it's just finding them, and then from
there we can use that information.

168
00:09:31.290 --> 00:09:34.690
>> Yeah, and
that's a great question because

169
00:09:34.690 --> 00:09:36.860
if I was joking around
at the beginning and

170
00:09:36.860 --> 00:09:40.220
saying we have permission to do
this as far as you guys know.

171
00:09:41.380 --> 00:09:45.710
The reality is is that
doing something like this,

172
00:09:45.710 --> 00:09:50.100
it probably would be more of
a courtesy to ask permission, but

173
00:09:50.100 --> 00:09:53.790
I'm not doing anything that
constitutes an attack at this point.

174
00:09:53.790 --> 00:09:59.310
I'm just going through and
kind of just rattling doorknobs, and

175
00:09:59.310 --> 00:10:02.450
that's not really to consider
to be any sort of attack.

176
00:10:02.450 --> 00:10:08.520
If I use the stuff, then that would be a
little bit more on the bad side of things.

177
00:10:08.520 --> 00:10:13.870
So what I have, you know, going
through here, let me see if I can take

178
00:10:13.870 --> 00:10:18.790
a look at some of this, is the alerts it
had, things it found or problem it found.

179

00:23:02.990 --> 00:23:08.940
You add this add-ons and extend it out
even beyond just the core things that,

404
00:23:08.940 --> 00:23:12.150
even something like Burp Suite,
or whatever, or even ZAP does.

405
00:23:12.150 --> 00:23:14.920
You can extend it out and
look for a whole bunch of things.

406
00:23:14.920 --> 00:23:16.450
And you really gotta like that,

407
00:23:16.450 --> 00:23:22.150

scanners will not go this far for you.

I want to say Nessus and

But those plug ins usually come from
the vendor, or you got to go through and

This one's got a pretty robust community.

00:23:37.270 --> 00:23:38.210
It's open source.

414

They're not trying to make money or
anything off of it.

00:23:41.410 --> 00:23:43.650
People write the things and
add them in and

now you've got an extensible very

That could actually change if

So [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

it looks like this one we hit the more

>> [LAUGH]
>> So, but in any case, you can see.

That you have something in
here that you can really

And so you really gotta love that.

The fact that this can look at stuff other

And even if you know you

It's always good to have

All right well Sean,

I noticed that we got, in the chat room,

Isn't Gmail technically still in beta,

Yeah, it's been released, so.

It's only been out for a month or two?

It came out August 11th.

>> So, the plugin authors

In the security world, I think everything

I wouldn't necessarily

It's just you've been

So that's kind of the way I look at it.

I'm sure there's some great paid tools out

472
00:26:43.265 --> 00:26:44.970
[LAUGH] But we pick our battles.

473
00:26:44.970 --> 00:26:45.590
All right.
Well,

474
00:26:45.590 --> 00:26:47.140
Shawn that was a great

475
00:26:47.140 --> 00:26:48.200
Thanks for being on the show.

00:26:50.980 --> 00:26:54.760
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Don Prezet and I'm Shawn Ariano.

478
00:26:54.760 --> 00:26:56.660
And we'll see you next time.

>> [LAUGH] Yeah, so it's very quickly and

What Responder is is it's a tool designed,

12

[LAUGH]

what Responder does is to really

Well, what is does it,

what are my proxy settings,

That's what it's supposed to eliminate.

It did do that, but you don't get

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike look at the post-exploitation tool, Intersect. Intersect generates a python script that can be run on a compromised system to gather information. They demonstrate how to load different modules in Intersect. Then they generate a script with the loaded modules.
episodes.title: Post-Attack with Intersect

00:17:31.610 --> 00:17:32.380
Very good.

305
00:17:32.380 --> 00:17:34.800
>> All right well ladies and gentlemen,
that's gonna do it for this one.

306
00:17:34.800 --> 00:17:36.250
We hope you enjoyed watching.

307
00:17:36.250 --> 00:17:38.570
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

308
00:17:38.570 --> 00:17:39.550
>> And I'm Sean Oriyano.

309
00:17:39.550 --> 00:17:41.230
>> And we'll see you next time.

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike talk about the pros and cons of using iOS and Android
episodes.title: Mobile and Android Pen Testing
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.180
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.180 --> 00:00:14.180
Hello and welcome to another episode
of ITProTV, I'm your host Mike Rodrick,

3
00:00:14.180 --> 00:00:16.230
with me today is your host Sean Oriyano.

4
00:00:16.230 --> 00:00:19.870
And in this episode, Sean,
we're gonna be taking a look at.

5
00:00:19.870 --> 00:00:22.710
Doing some penetration
testing from mobile devices.

6
00:00:22.710 --> 00:00:23.910
Something a little bit different.

7
00:00:23.910 --> 00:00:27.380
We've done some episodes, I know,
on pen-testing and things like that.

8
00:00:27.380 --> 00:00:28.360
Now we're gonna take a look at,

9
00:00:28.360 --> 00:00:32.430
when you say mobile device, assume we're
talking about phones and tablets, right?

10
00:00:32.430 --> 00:00:37.380
>> Yeah, we're moving into that territory
now is that we're moving off of,

11
00:00:37.380 --> 00:00:41.670
the mobile devices if
you wanna call it that.

12
00:00:41.670 --> 00:00:44.460
Of notebooks and stuff like that.

13
00:00:44.460 --> 00:00:46.725
Which were called mobile
devices at one point.

14
00:00:46.725 --> 00:00:49.870
>> [LAUGH]
>> Now we've got another class of,

15
00:00:49.870 --> 00:00:53.610
I guess maybe ultra mobile devices but
in any case we have.

16
00:00:53.610 --> 00:00:56.820
Where we are definitely
talking about smartphones,

17
00:00:56.820 --> 00:01:01.450
we're talking about tablets,
those type of foreign factor devices.

18
00:01:01.450 --> 00:01:04.460
So it's something that we really
haven't gotten into before.

19
00:01:04.460 --> 00:01:08.530
But we are moving in there, and
specifically we're gonna focus on,

20
00:01:08.530 --> 00:01:11.140
is using those devices.

21
00:01:11.140 --> 00:01:15.180
More then just a tool to be checked and
pen-tested.

22
00:01:15.180 --> 00:01:18.030
But instead to turn around and
actually use that

23
00:01:18.030 --> 00:01:21.670
as the tool that's doing the pen-testing,
and getting the prep for that.

24
00:01:21.670 --> 00:01:25.600
And fortunately, as the world
has embraced these devices and

25
00:01:25.600 --> 00:01:30.340
they've become a much more of
a ubiquitous thing to see.

26
00:01:30.340 --> 00:01:35.345
We have a situation where there's
increasing amounts support.

27
00:01:35.345 --> 00:01:39.135
For these devices as
a penetration testing tool.

28
00:01:39.135 --> 00:01:41.780
We're gonna get that process started for
you.

29
00:01:41.780 --> 00:01:43.925
And with all the episodes
we have coming up and

30
00:01:43.925 --> 00:01:47.687
getting it ready for
use as a penetration testing tool.

31
00:01:47.687 --> 00:01:52.257
>> It's a big game changer to say that
I don't need to bring a laptop around

32
00:01:52.257 --> 00:01:53.730
with me when I'm doing my pen-testing,

33
00:01:53.730 --> 00:01:56.387
now I can do it from one
of these mobile platforms.

34
00:01:56.387 --> 00:02:00.717
I think a lot of things have combined
as you said to really bring these to

35
00:02:00.717 --> 00:02:01.937
the forefront of pen-testing.

36
00:02:01.937 --> 00:02:03.357
The screens are larger.

37
00:02:03.357 --> 00:02:08.347
I've got tablets, big tablets,
better resolution, more processing power,

38
00:02:08.347 --> 00:02:10.380
more memory, better networking.

39
00:02:10.380 --> 00:02:12.260
I mean all of that combined, and

40
00:02:12.260 --> 00:02:15.100
as you said the broad
acceptance of these devices.

41
00:02:15.100 --> 00:02:18.980
All the development that's that
going on for these mobile platforms,

42
00:02:18.980 --> 00:02:22.350
all of that has kind of come together
in this culmination of, making a pretty

43
00:02:22.350 --> 00:02:26.680
impressive and efficient pen-testing tool
that I can carry around in my pocket.

44
00:02:26.680 --> 00:02:30.520
>> Yeah, indeed you can, and that's
the big benefit of having a mobile device,

45
00:02:30.520 --> 00:02:31.480
is that.

46
00:02:31.480 --> 00:02:35.770
If you set it up correctly, and
get the right tools for it,

47
00:02:35.770 --> 00:02:39.330
which is really kind of the tricky part
still, is getting the right tools.

48
00:02:39.330 --> 00:02:43.760
It's not as easy as it would be for
a desktop or laptop.

49
00:02:43.760 --> 00:02:48.130
Desktop or laptop, you still have to
do some looking in those platforms,

50
00:02:48.130 --> 00:02:51.590
but you can find them pretty readily.

51
00:02:51.590 --> 00:02:53.560
but as far as for tablets,

52
00:02:53.560 --> 00:02:57.390
tablets it does take a little
more time to find these things.

53
00:02:57.390 --> 00:03:01.170
Mobile devices of any type
takes a little bit more.

54
00:03:01.170 --> 00:03:04.900
And then which platform you choose
is really gonna impact your choices.

55
00:03:04.900 --> 00:03:09.720
>> I was really having trouble finding
any DDOS type tools in my iOS store.

56
00:03:10.760 --> 00:03:11.740
I don't want the deal is.

57
00:03:11.740 --> 00:03:13.582
I couldn't find any in there, right.

58
00:03:13.582 --> 00:03:14.094
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

59
00:03:14.094 --> 00:03:16.044
>> For some reason Apple is not putting

60
00:03:16.044 --> 00:03:17.560
those kind of tools in there.

61
00:03:17.560 --> 00:03:18.870
And we shouldn't expect that, right?

62
00:03:18.870 --> 00:03:21.910
If we have to go outside the norm
to find some of these tools.

63
00:03:21.910 --> 00:03:25.720
>> Yeah, you're definitely have to go way
off the beaten path to find a lot of these

64
00:03:25.720 --> 00:03:29.900
things, and that means that you've
got an extra level of burden,

65
00:03:29.900 --> 00:03:31.180
if you will, on you.

66
00:03:31.180 --> 00:03:33.260
To really test these things out.

67
00:03:33.260 --> 00:03:38.082
And get them ready to do that
whole pen-testing process.

68
00:03:38.082 --> 00:03:42.350
I've got on one of my devices here,

69
00:03:42.350 --> 00:03:47.800
I have a range of tools on it that I had
to spend a lot of time researching and

70
00:03:47.800 --> 00:03:49.700
getting prepped and ready for use.

71
00:03:49.700 --> 00:03:53.240
And it required for
me downloading the tools,

72
00:03:53.240 --> 00:03:56.880
installing them on a special
test device I have.

73
00:03:56.880 --> 00:04:00.810
And doing a lot of analysis on it, and
breaking open the distributables to

74
00:04:00.810 --> 00:04:02.980
see if there's anything in
there that was kinda suspect.

75
00:04:02.980 --> 00:04:08.030
And really doing a lot of checking
before I said, okay I'm gonna use

76
00:04:08.030 --> 00:04:13.000
this on another on a live device
rather my testing device.

77
00:04:13.000 --> 00:04:15.850
So, you will have to
do your due diligence,

78
00:04:15.850 --> 00:04:18.930
to borrow that term, you will have to
do your due diligence on these tools.

79
00:04:18.930 --> 00:04:23.310
But if you're willing to do that,
it can be quite rewarding.

80
00:04:24.850 --> 00:04:26.350
>> Nice.
So there are,

81
00:04:26.350 --> 00:04:29.420
when we look at the mobile devices,
we're really talking about iOS devices,

82
00:04:29.420 --> 00:04:31.700
Android devices things like that?

83
00:04:31.700 --> 00:04:35.800
>> Yeah that is what we're talking about,
is we're talking about mobile devices.

84
00:04:35.800 --> 00:04:38.720
Those two operating
systems are the big ones.

85
00:04:38.720 --> 00:04:42.535
There is another one
out there with Ubuntu.

86
00:04:42.535 --> 00:04:44.920
Ubuntu they are putting on
some mobile devices now,

87
00:04:44.920 --> 00:04:47.540
in fact you can get an Ubuntu phone.

88
00:04:47.540 --> 00:04:50.280
If you really want to do that and

89
00:04:50.280 --> 00:04:55.850
I'm aware that there are other platforms
out there that they run on mobile devices,

90
00:04:55.850 --> 00:05:01.160
but for all intents and purposes we don't
care, we just don't, not for today.

91
00:05:01.160 --> 00:05:04.570
I could care less about Blackberry today,

92
00:05:04.570 --> 00:05:06.653
I could care less about
the Windows platform today.

93
00:05:06.653 --> 00:05:10.111
It just that those ones,

94
00:05:10.111 --> 00:05:14.820
they have so they would have some tools
if someone's willing to make them.

95
00:05:14.820 --> 00:05:16.380
They probably have a couple but

96
00:05:16.380 --> 00:05:20.160
they don't have anything on the scale
that's something like the big boys have.

97
00:05:20.160 --> 00:05:22.120
And in this case, specifically, Android.

98
00:05:22.120 --> 00:05:26.370
Android is way leading the way as
far as the number of tools in here.

99
00:05:26.370 --> 00:05:29.730
That's why as far as
the tools we're using today.

100
00:05:31.630 --> 00:05:33.740
It's gonna be the Android OS.

101
00:05:33.740 --> 00:05:39.280
It's not gonna be iOS because iOS doesn't
really have that level of support.

102
00:05:39.280 --> 00:05:41.330
And that's we're talking about.

103
00:05:41.330 --> 00:05:46.490
For a bit here just because you're gonna
get someone watching this out there,

104
00:05:46.490 --> 00:05:49.790
but I don't wanna use an Android device,
I wanna use an iOS device.

105
00:05:50.930 --> 00:05:53.888
Okay, you're probably not gonna use it for

106
00:05:53.888 --> 00:05:56.914
pen-testing because support
really isn't there.

107
00:05:56.914 --> 00:06:00.450
I'm not saying you're not gonna find
anything, and this is not an Apple bashing

108
00:06:00.450 --> 00:06:05.350
thing at all, its just a case of the way
Apple has their stuff structured and

109
00:06:05.350 --> 00:06:10.480
keeps it so closed, and
keeps it so that's their baby.

110
00:06:10.480 --> 00:06:11.730
How it is with their stuff.

111
00:06:11.730 --> 00:06:15.320
They pride themselves on the fact that
we have this whole ecosystem set up,

112
00:06:15.320 --> 00:06:18.680
and that you have all these hurdles
that you gotta jump through.

113
00:06:18.680 --> 00:06:23.290
Android, on the other hand,
prides itself as being a lot more open,

114
00:06:23.290 --> 00:06:26.370
that really anybody can develop stuff for
it.

115
00:06:26.370 --> 00:06:29.240
It's another matter to get
stuff into Google Play Store,

116
00:06:29.240 --> 00:06:32.440
because that requires another
level of authorization.

117
00:06:32.440 --> 00:06:38.370
But, to get in and do stuff for
Android it's really not that difficult.

118
00:06:38.370 --> 00:06:40.700
They make a lot of tools available.

119
00:06:40.700 --> 00:06:45.320
In fact, they have things like
Android Studio that you can download and

120
00:06:45.320 --> 00:06:49.180
you can start writing,
applications on there fairly easily and

121
00:06:49.180 --> 00:06:51.280
you can load them on your devices.

122
00:06:51.280 --> 00:06:54.280
They do everything to
show you how to do that.

123
00:06:54.280 --> 00:06:56.040
So they're really helping you out.

124
00:06:56.040 --> 00:06:58.650
Where as iOS,
it's like you can get there, but.

125
00:06:59.750 --> 00:07:03.110
It's a lot tougher as developer,
to do something for and for

126
00:07:03.110 --> 00:07:08.050
us as people that like
to customize the device.

127
00:07:08.050 --> 00:07:12.370
Because, if we're doing ethical hacking,
we're gonna have to customize that device.

128
00:07:12.370 --> 00:07:13.793
We have very specific needs.

129
00:07:13.793 --> 00:07:14.360
We wanna be able to do that.

130
00:07:14.360 --> 00:07:18.990
We wanna be able to do a lot of
customization, get into the OS and

131
00:07:18.990 --> 00:07:24.710
get into the kernel and
do all sorts of little tricks with it.

132
00:07:24.710 --> 00:07:27.110
You can definitely do that.

133
00:07:27.110 --> 00:07:31.210
That's why it's such a great platform.

134
00:07:31.210 --> 00:07:36.190
Before I came here to do the shows here.

135
00:07:36.190 --> 00:07:40.280
I was playing around at home and

136
00:07:40.280 --> 00:07:46.050
I was looking for
different distributions of Android.

137
00:07:46.050 --> 00:07:50.125
And you have the ones that Google
releases and makes available,

138
00:07:50.125 --> 00:07:54.438
which you can get anyone you want,
you can get that all from Google.

139
00:07:54.438 --> 00:07:58.562
But the thing is, is that other people,
because it's customizable,

140
00:07:58.562 --> 00:08:00.289
they have actually grabbed.

141
00:08:00.289 --> 00:08:06.480
The source code which Google, again, makes
available to you, they're like go ahead.

142
00:08:06.480 --> 00:08:10.950
You can download that stuff and
if you're feeling ambitious enough or

143
00:08:10.950 --> 00:08:13.990
you have the skills,
you can customize those.

144
00:08:13.990 --> 00:08:18.003
And I was finding ones that were,
basically, like Android on a diet,

145
00:08:18.003 --> 00:08:21.131
it was like a quarter of
the size of regular Android, so

146
00:08:21.131 --> 00:08:23.119
it left all these resources on it.

147
00:08:23.119 --> 00:08:28.223
Found other ones that had all
utilities that people never used,

148
00:08:28.223 --> 00:08:31.164
that they stripped out of the thing.

149
00:08:31.164 --> 00:08:35.799
And ones that customized the kernel,
to be better for security testing, and

150
00:08:35.799 --> 00:08:38.100
just all sorts of stuff out there.

151
00:08:38.100 --> 00:08:41.240
You're not gonna find that with iOS,
you're just not.

152
00:08:41.240 --> 00:08:45.990
So maybe that will change,
at some point, in the future, but,

153
00:08:45.990 --> 00:08:50.240
right now, it's just not there for us.

154
00:08:50.240 --> 00:08:51.710
>> So, let's talk about some pro's and

155
00:08:51.710 --> 00:08:56.520
con's of moving to a mobile platform
like a phone or a tablet, versus,

156
00:08:56.520 --> 00:09:00.150
using a laptop or
a desktop to do your pen testing.

157
00:09:00.150 --> 00:09:02.114
I'm sure there's some
good things about it, and

158
00:09:02.114 --> 00:09:03.994
probably some things that
might not be as good.

159
00:09:03.994 --> 00:09:09.160
>> Yeah, there are some good things and
bad things about it.

160
00:09:09.160 --> 00:09:12.718
I might even say,
a more gentle way to put it,

161
00:09:12.718 --> 00:09:17.170
is that there's pros and
cons with anything, right?

162
00:09:17.170 --> 00:09:21.590
So I wouldn't necessarily say there's
anything bad about either platform.

163
00:09:21.590 --> 00:09:27.920
Some people would put it that way,
and you could put it that way.

164
00:09:27.920 --> 00:09:33.350
I tend to look it as,
is that there's things where a laptop and

165
00:09:33.350 --> 00:09:37.400
a mobile platform may not
be appropriate for, and

166
00:09:37.400 --> 00:09:41.070
you can make it work, but they're just
not appropriate to that environment.

167
00:09:41.070 --> 00:09:45.233
And the situation with
the traditional notebook,

168
00:09:45.233 --> 00:09:50.000
or environment like that,
that's in the Java for ages.

169
00:09:50.000 --> 00:09:51.050
That really has.

170
00:09:51.050 --> 00:09:52.277
So what can you say?

171
00:09:52.277 --> 00:09:55.358
It's proven to be very versatile,
very flexible,

172
00:09:55.358 --> 00:09:59.850
it's proven to be able to let us do
a whole bunch of different things with it.

173
00:09:59.850 --> 00:10:04.650
So you can say a lot of
great things about it.

174
00:10:04.650 --> 00:10:09.170
The big downside of it is,
is that it's why,

175
00:10:09.170 --> 00:10:13.270
you've got Notebook or something like
I've got here, that's very small and

176
00:10:13.270 --> 00:10:16.662
easy to carry, and
there's ones even smaller than this.

177
00:10:16.662 --> 00:10:22.150
They're still tough to conceal,

178
00:10:22.150 --> 00:10:27.550
and they have, different,
other limitations on that,

179
00:10:28.910 --> 00:10:31.250
so there will really be that side of it.

180
00:10:31.250 --> 00:10:36.300
But I tend to look at,
if you still go ahead,

181
00:10:36.300 --> 00:10:40.470
still keep a laptop or whatever in
your arsenal, it's still a great tool,

182
00:10:40.470 --> 00:10:42.390
the fact that we can do all
this great stuff with it.

183
00:10:42.390 --> 00:10:43.990
It's got all this hardware support,

184
00:10:43.990 --> 00:10:46.940
and we've got all that great stuff,
definitely keep it in there.

185
00:10:46.940 --> 00:10:49.905
Don't think that a mobile
platform is something that

186
00:10:49.905 --> 00:10:52.795
you necessarily need to
have the whole time.

187
00:10:52.795 --> 00:10:57.928
Now on the mobile side, the big benefits
there, are, of course, the mobility.

188
00:10:57.928 --> 00:11:03.949
Mobility is a lot higher there, than it is
on a device like a traditional notebook,

189
00:11:03.949 --> 00:11:08.335
so, I can carry this notebook around,
and I carry it back and

190
00:11:08.335 --> 00:11:10.586
forth from here and home a lot.

191
00:11:10.586 --> 00:11:15.151
It is easy to do, but
a mobile device is designed,

192
00:11:15.151 --> 00:11:19.360
specifically, for that low form factor.

193
00:11:19.360 --> 00:11:22.930
It's designed to run
much longer on a battery.

194
00:11:22.930 --> 00:11:26.368
That's another big plus with this,
is that in notebooks,

195
00:11:26.368 --> 00:11:29.200
you can get quite a bit of
battery power out of it.

196
00:11:29.200 --> 00:11:33.581
But, on average, a mobile device,
because of the way they're designed,

197
00:11:33.581 --> 00:11:36.661
you can actually get even
more battery life out of it,

198
00:11:36.661 --> 00:11:41.399
which I think is another really, really,
really big plus out of the whole thing.

199
00:11:41.399 --> 00:11:46.019
Now something else to look at on
a mobile device, is like I said,

200
00:11:46.019 --> 00:11:49.830
it's easy to conceal, it's very portable.

201
00:11:49.830 --> 00:11:53.716
If you're using something like Android,
it's getting to be very,

202
00:11:53.716 --> 00:11:54.930
very customizable.

203
00:11:55.990 --> 00:11:57.720
That's another big plus.

204
00:11:57.720 --> 00:12:01.590
That one didn't exist
until fairly recently.

205
00:12:01.590 --> 00:12:06.660
You did have before, smart devices,

206
00:12:06.660 --> 00:12:11.990
and smartphones, and tablets,
you did have operating systems out there,

207
00:12:11.990 --> 00:12:15.020
specifically, designed for
those types of devices.

208
00:12:15.020 --> 00:12:20.400
Nokia had theirs, and Blackberry
still has theirs, you've got that.

209
00:12:20.400 --> 00:12:24.800
But they were pretty much closed,
didn't lend themselves to customization.

210
00:12:24.800 --> 00:12:28.900
And if you did want to get in and
get the SDKs and all that for

211
00:12:28.900 --> 00:12:32.280
it, there really wasn't much power
in those devices anyway to do it.

212
00:12:32.280 --> 00:12:34.050
That's changed.

213
00:12:34.050 --> 00:12:35.960
They're very, very customizable.

214
00:12:35.960 --> 00:12:37.470
In fact,
they're almost as customizable, or

215
00:12:37.470 --> 00:12:40.640
even more customizable,
than even a desktop system.

216
00:12:40.640 --> 00:12:42.730
So you look at the battery power.

217
00:12:42.730 --> 00:12:44.490
You look at the portability.

218
00:12:44.490 --> 00:12:45.710
You look at the customizability.

219
00:12:45.710 --> 00:12:47.900
Those are all big pluses.

220
00:12:47.900 --> 00:12:52.520
Some downsides of it though, that may
make it not suitable for every situation,

221
00:12:52.520 --> 00:12:57.170
is the fact that you're gonna have
to get used to typing on a screen.

222
00:12:57.170 --> 00:13:01.375
Yeah, you can get a keyboard for it,
but that gets you back into, hey,

223
00:13:01.375 --> 00:13:03.815
you've really got a notebook

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike begin the process of installing Kali Nethunter. They discuss the various devices supported by Kali, and some of the pros and cons of each. They talk about the system requirements for installing Kali Nethunter. They demonstrate putting a Nexus 7 in developer mode and changing the USB connection to PTP in preparation for installation.
episodes.title: Installing Kali Nethunter

00:20:20.190 --> 00:20:24.110
Right now,
at least do a transfer the information,

361
00:20:24.110 --> 00:20:25.650
I need to transfer back and forth.

362
00:20:25.650 --> 00:20:28.086
I can already transfer photos and
stuff like that back and forth, and

00:20:28.086 --> 00:20:30.280
other data back and forth on this,
so that's not a problem.

00:20:30.280 --> 00:20:31.922
And that's not what I'm

00:20:31.922 --> 00:20:37.250
I'm gonna be actually transferring OS into

00:20:37.250 --> 00:20:39.289
So what you have to do is,
you have to enable,

00:20:39.289 --> 00:20:41.620
first of all it's called developer mode.

368
00:20:41.620 --> 00:20:44.631
Okay, now if you look

If it's enabled, you'll see it under the

It ain't there, it's not enabled.

00:20:54.355 --> 00:20:56.470
Okay, so let's go ahead and enable that.

00:20:56.470 --> 00:21:01.015
The way you enable that is,

okay, well were just in about tablet,

There's no switches, look,

it's just not really obvious,
it's a little trick.

00:21:13.370 --> 00:21:15.270
You've got the build number in here.

If you start tapping on it,

It'll keep ticking down until you

okay, you're a developer now.

00:21:36.860 --> 00:21:41.191
So, nothing changed here, what

00:21:41.191 --> 00:21:44.467
down at the bottom,

00:21:44.467 --> 00:21:46.361
Okay, so now you'll click on that.

00:21:46.361 --> 00:21:52.219
And what you have to do is, when you go

00:21:52.219 --> 00:21:57.810

00:21:57.810 --> 00:22:00.790
When we start looking at this thing,

we're looking at some stuff

00:22:04.340 --> 00:22:08.300
You also, typically,
be called USB debugging.

That's what it's called in the vast

00:22:13.470 --> 00:22:17.930
So you're gonna see something saying,

00:22:17.930 --> 00:22:20.318
So it says allow USB debugging?

Yeah, we wanna to do that,

00:22:21.590 --> 00:22:27.140

00:22:33.650 --> 00:22:38.595
Sometimes it comes up with another

After you've gone through and

that stays off.

00:23:17.084 --> 00:23:21.721
Don't leave that on,

00:23:21.721 --> 00:23:24.325
Okay, so
that's the first thing you gotta do,

there is another thing

As I swipe down from the top in here,

You can see it says USB

that's what the top dialog says.

00:23:37.890 --> 00:23:42.975
The bottom one over here says,

00:23:42.975 --> 00:23:45.448
Well, if I tap on that it's telling me,

00:23:45.448 --> 00:23:47.099
it is connected as a media device.

00:23:47.099 --> 00:23:54.203
And what I'm looking for

You can't use this as a media device.

It has to be set up as a PTP device, so

00:24:06.652 --> 00:24:10.260
Now, it's on my computer right now.

00:24:10.260 --> 00:24:13.160
We don't need to take

And there's nothing really

00:24:23.310 --> 00:24:26.070
And that's the next thing that will

00:24:28.050 --> 00:24:33.060
At this point, you're actually in a spot

So, FYI, if your device,

sometimes there may be reasons why

if the system is still saying that,
oh, I can't transfer stuff over and

00:24:56.850 --> 00:24:58.770
you've got USB debugging enabled.

00:24:58.770 --> 00:25:01.170
If it still sits here and throws fits,

00:25:01.170 --> 00:25:05.990
look over here when you plug it

00:25:05.990 --> 00:25:10.280
the USB connection up, and
see, well, is it on PTP?

00:25:10.280 --> 00:25:14.066
If that's the case already,

00:25:14.066 --> 00:25:17.290
It's just kind of a way of quickly

00:25:17.290 --> 00:25:18.880
okay, now I know what you're doing.

Sometimes Android gets a little stupid in

00:25:23.605 --> 00:25:27.670

00:25:27.670 --> 00:25:33.800
Okay, so, we're in really good shape to

00:25:33.800 --> 00:25:39.510
If this is stock Android and

00:25:44.640 --> 00:25:49.930
If it's not a stock Android device or you

00:25:49.930 --> 00:25:52.170
Maybe you got it used and

But right now, we have a device that,

00:26:01.160 --> 00:26:06.370
would be something that I could actually

00:26:06.370 --> 00:26:13.037
So remember, you gotta do these things

And one other word of caution that I

This micro USB cable

If that cable's an after-market cable,

In which case you need to get the one

The other thing that could

If you don't have those things or

00:27:24.740 --> 00:27:29.700

00:27:29.700 --> 00:27:31.980
So everything's got a safety

But there are gotchas that

00:27:35.640 --> 00:27:39.496
But right now, yeah, we've got

00:27:43.275 --> 00:27:46.770

We got the appropriate hardware,

Made sure we had a good backup of it,

And then we disabled MTP,

It doesn't see it as just a media thing

00:28:20.110 --> 00:28:24.770
And at that point, we're close to

>> Yeah, you're right there to

Kali can be the very next thing or there

But you're right there where you need

And we'll talk about that step that you

It's an important thing because not

It's also something that when you

As well as if you wanna load

So we're gonna keep you

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike continue the process of installing Kali Nethunter on a Nexus 7. They demonstrate using the Nexus Root Toolkit. They use NRT to backup the device, install the necessary drivers, and unlock the bootloader. They also show how to restore a soft-bricked device using the flash stock and unroot option.
episodes.title: Installing Kali Nethunter Part 2

But after you work with a customer or

Cool, it's just a really,

It's a very, very nice utility.

00:18:14.604 --> 00:18:22.320

00:18:22.320 --> 00:18:26.230
If you need to do it on another device,

00:18:26.230 --> 00:18:29.250

00:18:39.200 --> 00:18:44.960

00:18:48.995 --> 00:18:50.874

00:18:50.874 --> 00:18:57.450

You can get it pretty close, and if you're

00:19:01.770 --> 00:19:03.360
it'll take some effort.

00:19:03.360 --> 00:19:07.347
But you can root it, and let's say you

00:19:07.347 --> 00:19:08.691
something bad happens.

00:19:08.691 --> 00:19:12.530
And you're like oh, well heck,

00:19:12.530 --> 00:19:17.303
No, those cases you might very well do a

00:19:17.303 --> 00:19:22.380

00:19:22.380 --> 00:19:24.990
In fact, with some of the Samsung devices,

00:19:24.990 --> 00:19:29.010

00:19:29.010 --> 00:19:34.590
And if you tamper with the device it'll

00:19:34.590 --> 00:19:38.670
that won't stop the device from working,
but if Samsung looks at it,

00:19:38.670 --> 00:19:40.750
there's no way to reset that fuse.

00:19:40.750 --> 00:19:43.170
So they look at it and go,

00:19:46.220 --> 00:19:50.680
So you're either buying a new device or

00:19:50.680 --> 00:19:51.980

00:19:51.980 --> 00:19:54.890
So there could be little pitfalls there.

333
00:19:54.890 --> 00:19:59.341
In fact KNOX will even do other stuff to
the system too to block you from doing

334
00:19:59.341 --> 00:20:00.624

335
00:20:00.624 --> 00:20:04.142
It's designed to keep you out of trouble,
but it can also be frustrating when those

00:20:04.142 --> 00:20:07.370
things that it thinks it's doing
to keep you out of trouble.

00:20:07.370 --> 00:20:11.780
It's great if you are the average Joe and
you're using this device and

But if you're trying to

00:20:17.033 --> 00:20:18.522
[SOUND] Get your hands off that.

00:20:18.522 --> 00:20:20.100
It can be really frustrating.

00:20:20.100 --> 00:20:22.940
But, in any case,
if you have those devices,

you will not fix those devices with this,
this is strictly for Nexus devices.

00:20:28.750 --> 00:20:30.110
Never, ever forget that.

00:20:30.110 --> 00:20:33.340
You plug one of the other ones in and

it won't detect it because

It's not build into the database and

you can eventually get it to do it, but

350
00:20:43.910 --> 00:20:46.630

351
00:20:46.630 --> 00:20:50.840
And hopefully it's not irreparably

352
00:20:50.840 --> 00:20:55.141
The person that wrote this wrote it kind

00:20:55.141 --> 00:20:59.443

It works really well for doing that.

00:21:04.202 --> 00:21:07.830
And the fact that it also helps with

357
00:21:07.830 --> 00:21:11.142
I mean, this thing can help you if you're
having problems loading another operating

00:21:11.142 --> 00:21:13.740
system, something that

359
00:21:13.740 --> 00:21:19.008
You load Kali NetHunter

00:21:19.008 --> 00:21:22.342
Let's say I load it in there and

00:21:31.490 --> 00:21:33.660
I know it's there, but
