364
00:21:33.660 --> 00:21:38.090
Well, you can use this device to
do what's called wiping the cache.

365
00:21:38.090 --> 00:21:41.228
Because when you start up
an Android device the first time,

366
00:21:41.228 --> 00:21:43.436
it actually takes the operating system.

367
00:21:43.436 --> 00:21:45.988
And why it takes so long to start up
the first time is it takes that and

368
00:21:45.988 --> 00:21:47.710
does kinda like it does with Java.

369
00:21:47.710 --> 00:21:51.148
It kind of takes the thing,
compiles it, and puts it in the cache.

370
00:21:51.148 --> 00:21:54.414
So it's gonna go to that cache to run it.

371
00:21:54.414 --> 00:21:57.680
So if Kali NetHunter hasn't been cached
yet and there is something already there,

372
00:21:57.680 --> 00:22:01.380
it may very well go to this cache,
the Dalvik-cache is what they call it.

373
00:22:01.380 --> 00:22:06.090
They call it something else now,
but it goes there.

374
00:22:06.090 --> 00:22:08.270
And so if there is something in there,

375
00:22:08.270 --> 00:22:11.320
the device may boot into
what it previously there.

376
00:22:11.320 --> 00:22:14.040
Well, one of the ways
you can get that cache,

377
00:22:14.040 --> 00:22:18.764
which also is called the user data cache,
the way to get rid of that cache is just

378
00:22:18.764 --> 00:22:21.985
to go into something like
the Nexus Root Toolkit, and

379
00:22:21.985 --> 00:22:25.510
go into advanced utilities and
say, pop, you're dead.

380
00:22:25.510 --> 00:22:29.850
And it will then reboot the device and
all the sudden,

381
00:22:29.850 --> 00:22:34.100
hey, everything's working great and
your happy.

382
00:22:34.100 --> 00:22:36.320
So it can help you out dramatically.

383
00:22:36.320 --> 00:22:38.546
Do you need the Nexus Root Toolkit
to wipe the cache?

384
00:22:38.546 --> 00:22:42.269
No, there's little button combinations
you can do when you power on the device.

385
00:22:42.269 --> 00:22:46.870
But this will make things just a lot
easier for you at the end of the day.

386
00:22:47.990 --> 00:22:49.230
>> Very good.

All right well, Sean,

At this point our device is pretty close,

>> Yeah, actually it's very,

At this point, we said in the previous

It's a very helpful tool in the event

403
00:23:50.325 --> 00:23:55.110

devise can take some time to do.

404
00:23:55.110 --> 00:23:56.950
Everything can be be right here.

00:23:56.950 --> 00:23:57.860
>> Very good.

406
00:23:57.860 --> 00:23:59.350
All right, well you know what that means.

407
00:23:59.350 --> 00:24:00.850
We're out of time on this episode.

408
00:24:00.850 --> 00:24:04.160
We're gonna have to put off installing
Kali NetHunter to the next one.

409
00:24:04.160 --> 00:24:06.520
So make sure you come back and
check us out.

410
00:24:06.520 --> 00:24:09.230
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

00:24:10.090 --> 00:24:11.203

00:19:58.056 --> 00:19:58.937

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike explore some post-installation tasks on Kali Nethunter.  These tasks include updating applications and configuring your Google account for access to Google Play. They also talk about installing additional tools and configuring them for first use. Then they go over some external accessories to use with Kali Nethunter, like an OTG cable, external wireless and bluetooth adapters, and cases.
episodes.title: Post-Installation Tasks

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike talk about the advantages of building your own Pwn Pad and Pwn Phone. They take a look at available hardware choices, including external adapters. They also go over what will be needed to build a Pwn Pad, including Pwn Pad 2014 Community Edition and a physical machine running Linux.
episodes.title: Pwn Pad and Pwn Phone

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike begin the process of creating a Pwn Pad on a Nexus 7. They look at setting up a Linux Ubuntu 12.4 machine with all of the tools needed to create a Pwn Pad. After downloading the Pwn Pad 2014 Community Edition, they begin the installation.
episodes.title: Creating Your Own Pwn Pad

episodes.description: In this episode Sean and Mike explore some adapters that can be used with a Pwn Pad. They look at the TP-Link USB adapter as well as the SENA UD100 Industrial Bluetooth USB Adapter. The Pwn Pad is designed to work with these adapters, and extends the range and functionality of the Pwn Pad.
episodes.title: Pwn Pad Wifi & Bluetooth

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike look at some of the USB-based attacks that can be done with Kali Nethunter. They look at BadUSB MITM Attack which is a man-in-the-middle attack, as well as the HID Keyboard Attack which allows keystrokes to be sent from Kali Nethunter to the attack target.

It's something we didn't mention I think,

Again, you could be sitting in the lobby

So this goes right in the pocket.

Now I've got an access point that's very,

And in my case, I can turn this

But it's also, I do use this as

Its got calls, so I can be sitting there

It's very, very simple,

Well, who are you looking for?

Who are you looking for?

You can't say, well you could, but it's a

This, I'm like, what?

They expect those sorts of things, so

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike demonstrate configuring a Pwn Pad and an application called SSL Strip. this application allows you to perform a MiTM attack by preventing the victim from setting up an SSL connection.
episodes.title: MiTM with SSL Strip
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.303
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.303 --> 00:00:12.830
Hello, and
welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:12.830 --> 00:00:15.000
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:15.000 --> 00:00:16.950
With me today is Mr Sean Oriyano.

5
00:00:16.950 --> 00:00:20.140
In this episode,
Sean's gonna help us take a look at

6
00:00:20.140 --> 00:00:24.630
a man in the middle attack using
something called SSL strip.

7
00:00:24.630 --> 00:00:25.920
So Sean tell us about this.

8
00:00:25.920 --> 00:00:29.460
Man in the middle, we probably should
be familiar with this concept,

9
00:00:29.460 --> 00:00:34.260
man in the middle, sitting in between
a conversation and intercepting traffic,

10
00:00:34.260 --> 00:00:38.210
and maybe just sniffing it, maybe
modifying it, or something like that.

11
00:00:38.210 --> 00:00:40.770
But SSL Strip, how does that fit in here?

12
00:00:40.770 --> 00:00:44.820
>> Well,
it's a way of actually bumping up or

13
00:00:44.820 --> 00:00:49.020
stepping up the ante on
man in the middle attacks.

14
00:00:49.020 --> 00:00:53.630
As you should already know, a man in the
middle is, like Mike was saying, you got

15
00:00:53.630 --> 00:00:58.810
two points that are having a conversation,
and you've got something right,

16
00:00:58.810 --> 00:01:01.970
someone sitting right in the middle,
another party, us,

17
00:01:01.970 --> 00:01:06.690
that are actually intercepting those
communications, and passing them through.

18
00:01:06.690 --> 00:01:11.800
Now they could be just passively
letting those things go by, or they

19
00:01:11.800 --> 00:01:16.610
could be actively doing something, that's
really kind of up to you at that point.

20
00:01:16.610 --> 00:01:17.910
What we're gonna be seeing here is,

21
00:01:17.910 --> 00:01:21.480
we're gonna see a way that we can
actually do both, if we want.

22
00:01:21.480 --> 00:01:25.520
We can take the active role or
the passive, sit back, and watch role.

23
00:01:25.520 --> 00:01:30.120
So it's a pretty interesting proposition.

24
00:01:30.120 --> 00:01:35.238
What really bumps us up is that,
it's something that the PWN Pad has,

25
00:01:35.238 --> 00:01:38.540
but like I said, bumps up the ante.

26
00:01:38.540 --> 00:01:40.060
And how does it bump up the ante?

27
00:01:40.060 --> 00:01:42.900
Well, pay attention to what
the name of this thing is,

28
00:01:42.900 --> 00:01:44.910
it's called SSL Strip for a reason.

29
00:01:44.910 --> 00:01:47.640
>> I was just gonna say, I can
prevent that man in the middle attack,

30
00:01:47.640 --> 00:01:50.410
I'm just gonna encrypt my traffic,
I'm gonna use SSL.

31
00:01:50.410 --> 00:01:52.751
That way you can intercept it
all you want, you can't read it.

32
00:01:52.751 --> 00:01:54.110
It's gonna be [CROSSTALK].

33
00:01:54.110 --> 00:01:59.509
>> No, you're not.
>> [LAUGH]

34
00:01:59.509 --> 00:02:01.942
>> So I've taken it that you're gonna be

35
00:02:01.942 --> 00:02:07.590
removing my protection, and leaving me
out there exposed for the world to see.

36
00:02:07.590 --> 00:02:08.440
>> Yeah, pretty much.

37
00:02:08.440 --> 00:02:15.047
That's what the objective here is to do,
is to remove that SSL capability,

38
00:02:15.047 --> 00:02:19.914
and it's not like you think,
let me put that out there.

39
00:02:19.914 --> 00:02:21.419
When I describe it,

40
00:02:21.419 --> 00:02:26.912
you'll see it's a little bit different
than what you think, cuz you're

41
00:02:26.912 --> 00:02:32.329
thinking it's like how does he get
a tool to take SSL off of a connection.

42
00:02:32.329 --> 00:02:34.790
Well we're gonna clear
that up because it's the,

43
00:02:34.790 --> 00:02:38.340
I know there's probably already
things going through people's minds,

44
00:02:38.340 --> 00:02:41.850
about well that doesn't sound
like something that can happen.

45
00:02:41.850 --> 00:02:46.350
Well, no, not the way you're thinking,
but let me talk about that.

46
00:02:46.350 --> 00:02:50.350
What you may be thinking, right now,
is that you have a client, and

47
00:02:50.350 --> 00:02:53.470
you're talking to server, and
that's an SSL encrypted session,

48
00:02:53.470 --> 00:02:57.970
and I'm jumping in the middle of it,
and peeling away that SSL layer.

49
00:02:57.970 --> 00:02:58.796
It's not overdoing.

50
00:02:58.796 --> 00:03:04.060
We are, actually,
looking for SSL sessions,

51
00:03:04.060 --> 00:03:08.900
stuff that are using HTTPS, and then
what we're doing is intercepting those

52
00:03:08.900 --> 00:03:13.980
requests, prior to them getting to
the server, so we're causing them, or

53
00:03:13.980 --> 00:03:19.400
fooling them into, actually, sending that
request out, we intercept the request.

54
00:03:19.400 --> 00:03:24.584
And then, we either pass it through to the
legitimate target, or we have it set up,

55
00:03:24.584 --> 00:03:28.952
the target on the other side is an HTTP
site, so we just go through, and

56
00:03:28.952 --> 00:03:33.421
they connect to us, using, or
they try to connect to us, using HTTPs.

57
00:03:33.421 --> 00:03:38.599
Or connect to their target using Agent PS,
but they get through us, we take that

58
00:03:38.599 --> 00:03:43.778
SSL request, peel it off, and just forward
it right on through the other side,

59
00:03:43.778 --> 00:03:49.139
to something that's using HTTP, a URL
that we created, or some other location.

60
00:03:49.139 --> 00:03:52.263
And so, it's not peeling it
off in an existing session,

61
00:03:52.263 --> 00:03:56.689
it's preventing that session from
occurring, and then fooling the user into,

62
00:03:56.689 --> 00:03:59.443
actually, believing
that everything's fine.

63
00:03:59.443 --> 00:04:02.811
>> They might still have that little
S at the end of their HTTP up there.

64
00:04:02.811 --> 00:04:03.808
>> They might.

65
00:04:03.808 --> 00:04:08.111
>> Might still have that lock up in their
browser or whatever indicator they've got,

66
00:04:08.111 --> 00:04:11.160
but they really didn't ever
have a secure connection.

67
00:04:11.160 --> 00:04:15.947
>> Yeah, under certain conditions
that would still appear up there, and

68
00:04:15.947 --> 00:04:17.938
the way I look at it really is,

69
00:04:17.938 --> 00:04:22.639
even if you look at the fact that if I
mapped you over to an HTTP site, and

70
00:04:22.639 --> 00:04:27.701
that lock did disappear, how many people
do you think really look at that?

71
00:04:27.701 --> 00:04:29.514
>> Most people don't, they really don't.

72
00:04:29.514 --> 00:04:30.163
>> Yeah, so.

73
00:04:30.163 --> 00:04:31.440
>> They should, but they don't.

74
00:04:31.440 --> 00:04:36.752
>> Yeah, we tell them all these safety
things and security awareness things,

75
00:04:36.752 --> 00:04:40.829
and they're probably not paying
attention to most of it.

76
00:04:40.829 --> 00:04:45.923
So what we're gonna do is we're gonna
take a look at how this takes place,

77
00:04:45.923 --> 00:04:51.350
it's actually incredibly and
deceptively simple on what's going on.

78
00:04:51.350 --> 00:04:57.030
So what we have here is,
I'm gonna have my Pwn Pad, once again.

79
00:04:58.030 --> 00:05:01.352
So I have my Pwn Pad sitting here.

80
00:05:01.352 --> 00:05:04.520
And I'm slide that up front and
center, here a bit, for you.

81
00:05:04.520 --> 00:05:08.740
So what you're gonna do is,
we have our various tools.

82
00:05:08.740 --> 00:05:11.840
What we see is, we see the little guy
asking for a passport right there.

83
00:05:11.840 --> 00:05:18.330
So that's our SSL Strip deal, and
that brings up this menu right here.

84
00:05:18.330 --> 00:05:24.180
Now, again, based on the situation that
we're in, I'm showing you the tool,

85
00:05:24.180 --> 00:05:29.278
and telling you what it does, but
we're gonna play on the safe side.

86
00:05:29.278 --> 00:05:32.870
I don't wanna all of a sudden do this
because we do have a live network here.

87
00:05:32.870 --> 00:05:35.724
I do not wanna start doing this, and
there's other people in the building,

88
00:05:35.724 --> 00:05:38.845
all of a sudden, someone's credit card
number comes across that's different.

89
00:05:38.845 --> 00:05:40.140
>> [LAUGH]
>> But I don't wanna start

90
00:05:40.140 --> 00:05:42.810
intercepting things, and
have them display here.

91
00:05:42.810 --> 00:05:47.760
So we're gonna set it up, and
show you just how easy it is.

92
00:05:47.760 --> 00:05:52.830
Okay, so what this is gonna do is when you

93
00:05:52.830 --> 00:05:56.540
plug this thing into a network,
either connect it to a wireless network or

94
00:05:56.540 --> 00:06:00.650
a wired network, what's gonna happen is
is it's gonna start looking for requests.

95
00:06:00.650 --> 00:06:04.320
So what it's asking here for
you, is that first of all,

96
00:06:04.320 --> 00:06:08.580
presumably you'd have your
good old wired connection or

97
00:06:08.580 --> 00:06:11.860
wireless connection to the Internet,
using whatever.

98
00:06:11.860 --> 00:06:17.230
And then, you've got another
interface that you're gonna sniff on.

99
00:06:17.230 --> 00:06:21.330
So what you're gonna do is,
I have this list here,

100
00:06:21.330 --> 00:06:25.560
the list here has my ethernet connections,
two WLAN connections.

101
00:06:25.560 --> 00:06:28.080
And the reason why it has two WLANs,
even though there isn't another one

102
00:06:28.080 --> 00:06:31.540
plugged in here is,
it's recognizing the internal one.

103
00:06:31.540 --> 00:06:35.560
And then, it's also optimized and
programmed, this is the Pwn Pad after all,

104
00:06:35.560 --> 00:06:39.480
to use that TP-LINK device, so
they've already coded it in there.

105
00:06:39.480 --> 00:06:42.360
So we've got that plus
a couple other ones.

106
00:06:42.360 --> 00:06:46.710
What's it's asking me is which one
do you want to do your sniffing on?

107
00:06:46.710 --> 00:06:50.540
Right now, none of these interfaces
would actually work for sniffing,

108
00:06:50.540 --> 00:06:53.367
even though it's recognizing
the ones internally,

109
00:06:53.367 --> 00:06:57.135
those internal ones aren't gonna
work because remember what we said,

110
00:06:57.135 --> 00:07:01.249
those WiFI ones, typically, are limited
on the capabilities internally.

111
00:07:01.249 --> 00:07:05.353
So it means we would have to get
something like this, to do this,

112
00:07:05.353 --> 00:07:08.050
if we're gonna sniff on wireless.

113
00:07:08.050 --> 00:07:14.210
So what to do now at this point is,
all we'd have to do, and this is,

114
00:07:14.210 --> 00:07:19.420
literally, how easy it is, you wanna sniff
on interface, let's say I wanna sniff on,

115
00:07:19.420 --> 00:07:25.220
if I had my wired adaptor plugged
out here, I could say ETH 0,

116
00:07:25.220 --> 00:07:29.430
which is actually one right there.

117
00:07:29.430 --> 00:07:32.900
Hit enter, and it's gonna go ahead,
and start this thing up.

118
00:07:34.290 --> 00:07:39.890
And once it goes ahead and starts this
thing up, now what's gonna happen is that,

119
00:07:39.890 --> 00:07:43.980
when credentials start
passing over the wire, and

120
00:07:43.980 --> 00:07:48.470
it picks up a session,
it will intercept it, and

121
